{{Infobox officeholder | name = Karl Korinek | image = Karl Korinek (cropped).jpg | office = [[List of Presidents of the Constitutional Court (Austria)|President of the Constitutional Court]] | appointer = | vicepresident = [[Brigitte Bierlein]] | term_start = January 1, 2003 | term_end = April 30, 2008 | predecessor = [[Ludwig Adamovich Jr.]] | successor = [[Gerhart Holzinger]] | office1 = [[List of Vice Presidents of the Constitutional Court (Austria)|Vice President of the Constitutional Court]] | term_start1 = January 1, 1999 | term_end1 = December 31, 2002 | appointer1 = | president1 = [[Ludwig Adamovich Jr.]] | predecessor1 = Karl Piska | successor1 = [[Brigitte Bierlein]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1940|12|7|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Vienna]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|3|9|1940|12|7|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Vienna]] | father = [[Franz Korinek]] | mother = Viktoria Korinek | party = [[Austrian People's Party]] | children = 2 | alma_mater = [[University of Vienna]] }} '''Karl Korinek''' (December 7, 1940 – March 9, 2017) was an [[Austria]]n [[jurist|constitutional scholar]] and educator. Korinek taught [[law]] at the [[University of Graz]], the [[Vienna University of Economics and Business]], the [[University of Vienna]], and the [[Danube University Krems]]. In 1978, Korinek was appointed to the Austrian [[Constitutional Court (Austria)|Constitutional Court]]; he served as the president of the court from 2003 until his retirement in 2008.
Although a member of the [[Austrian People's Party]] and an outspoken conservative in private life, Korinek was considered non-partisan in his jurisprudence. He clashed with [[Wolfgang Schüssel]] on health care and immigration reform and with [[Jörg Haider]] on minority protection matters; he received praise from political opponents for his firm stance on [[human rights]] issues in general. Korinek has authored several books and more than 250 scholarly papers. Respected across party boundaries, he is widely regarded as one of the most influential legal scholars in recent Austrian history.
== Early life ==
Karl Korinek was born December 12, 1940 in [[Vienna]] as the son of [[Franz Korinek]], a lawyer and future politician, and his wife Viktoria.<ref name="parlcv">{{cite web|url=https://www.parlament.gv.at/WWER/PAD_17148/| title=Dr. Dr. h.c. Karl Korinek| website=[[Austrian Parliament]]| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref name="danubecv">{{cite web|url=https://www.donau-uni.ac.at/imperia/md/content/studium/euro/law/cvfaculty/cv_korinek.pdf| title=Präs. o. Univ.-Prof. i. R. Dr. Karl Korinek: Lebenslauf in Stichworten| website=[[Danube University Krems]]| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref>
Korinek grew up [[Catholic Church|Catholic]]. The family was conservative; Korinek's father joined the [[Austrian People's Party]] after the end of [[World War II]] and went on to become General Secretary of the [[Austrian Economic Chamber]], the national entrepreneurs' and industrialists' advocacy group; he later also served as the [[Ministry of Finance (Austria)|minister of finance]] for a term.<ref name="danubecv"/><ref name="dirigent">{{cite web|url=https://diepresse.com/home/innenpolitik/5181383/Karl-Korinek_Dirigent-des-VfGH-und-grosser-Staatsrechtsleher| title=Karl Korinek: "Dirigent" des VfGH und großer Staatsrechtsleher| website=[[Die Presse]]| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref>
Korinek received his secondary education at the [[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]] [[Mariahilf]], a school with special emphasis on the classical humanities.<ref name="danubecv"/>
== Career ==
Following his graduation from the [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] in 1958, Korinek enrolled at the [[University of Vienna]] to study [[law]], receiving his [[Doctor of Law|doctorate]] in 1963. He spent the next year working as a trainee at various Viennese courts. In 1964, he went to work as an in-house legal consultant for the [[Austrian Economic Chamber]]. In addition to his day job in the bureaucracy, Korinek continued to pursue an academic career. In 1970, he submitted his [[habilitation]] thesis to the Faculty of Legal and Political Science ({{lang-de|Rechts- und Staatswissenschaften}}) at the [[University of Salzburg]]. In 1973, he left the Chamber to accept an appointment to full professor of public law ({{lang|de|öffentliches Recht}}) at the [[University of Graz]]. After three years in Graz, Korinek returned to the capital to become a professor at the [[Vienna University of Economics and Business]], a position he held until he moved on to the [[University of Vienna]] in 1995.<ref name="parlcv"/><ref name="danubecv"/><ref name="steirische">{{cite web|url=http://www.kommunikation.steiermark.at/cms/beitrag/11693797/374565/| title=Höchste steirische Auszeichnung für Korinek| website=[[Styria|Land Steiermark]]| date=August 31, 2006| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref>
Starting in 1997, he also taught at the [[Danube University Krems]].<ref name="danubecv"/>
In addition to his academic commitments, Korinek held a considerable number of extramural positions. From 1986 to 1992, Korinek was president of the [[Austrian Standards Institute]]; from 1987 to 2002, he also sat on the board of the [[Deutsches Institut für Normung]].<ref name="parlcv"/><ref name="danubecv"/> In 1999, he became a member of the board of directors of the [[Vienna State Opera]].<ref name="staatsoper">{{cite web|url=https://www.wiener-staatsoper.at/die-staatsoper/aktuelles/detail/news/zum-tod-von-karl-korinek/| title=Zum Tod von Karl Korinek| website=[[Vienna State Opera]]| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref><ref name="oecvcv">{{cite web|url=https://www.oecv.at/Biolex/Detail/11600324| title=Karl Korinek| website=[[Cartellverband]]| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref><ref name="komturkreuz">{{cite web|url=https://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20060217_OTS0144/hoechste-auszeichnung-des-landes-fuer-prof-dr-karl-korinek| title=Höchste Auszeichnung des Landes für Prof. Dr. Karl Korinek| website=[[Austria Press Agency]]| date=February 17, 2006| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> He also served on the boards of directors of a number of publicly traded companies and [[non-governmental organization|NGO]]s,<ref name="ggeab">{{cite web|url=http://www.bundespraesident.at/newsdetail/artikel/grosses-goldenes-ehrenzeichen-am-bande-an-praesident-univ-prof-dr-karl-korinek-und-praesident-dr/| title=Großes Goldenes Ehrenzeichen am Bande an Präsident Univ. Prof. Dr. Karl Korinek| website=[[President of Austria|Office of the President of Austria]]| date=December 13, 2006| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> most notably the [[Uniqa Insurance Group]] and the [[ERSTE Foundation]].<ref name="oecvcv"/><ref name="unabhaengige">{{cite web|url=https://derstandard.at/1277338475613/Unabhaengige-Kandidaten-haben-keine-Chance| title=Unabhängige Kandidaten haben keine Chance| date=July 19, 2010| accessdate=2018-06-07| website=[[Der Standard]]}}</ref>
In 1998, he was invited to join the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]].<ref name="danubecv"/><ref name="vfghcv"/>
In 1978, Korinek was appointed to the Austrian [[Constitutional Court (Austria)|Constitutional Court]]. He was promoted to vice president of the court in 1999, to president in 2003.<ref name="parlcv"/><ref name="danubecv"/><ref name="vfghcv"/> Korinek retired from his university positions and from most other responsibilities when he assumed the presidency. He kept his seat on the board of the State Opera, a side job that was particularly dear to him.<ref name="ggeab"/><ref name="quart">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.quart-online.at/pdf/quart_2006_02/q2006_02_25.pdf| title=Karl der Große?| magazine=Quart| issue=2| date=2016| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref>
In early 2003, the cabinet of then-[[Chancellor of Austria|Chancellor]] [[Wolfgang Schüssel]] launched the Austria Convention ({{lang|de|Österreich-Konvent}}), a conference of legal scholars and public intellectuals tasked with drafting a new constitution for Austria. The existing constitution, exceptionally bulky and difficult to navigate, had been posing serious technical challenges to legislators and constitutional justices for decades.<ref>{{cite book|ref=harv | author-last1=Berka| author-first1 = Walter | title=Verfassungsrecht| edition=6th| publisher=Österreich Verlag| place=Vienna| date=2016| isbn=978-3-7046-7281-0|pages=14−15, 21−22, 52, 124}}</ref> The Convention was charged with exploring reform.<ref>Berka (2016), pp. 14−16.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://neuwal.com/2015/01/28/was-ist-bzw-war-der-oesterreich-konvent/| title=Was ist bzw. war der Österreich-Konvent?| website=Neuwal| accessdate=2018-06-05}}</ref> Korinek was a member of the Convention from its launch to its conclusion in 2005.<ref name="parlcv"/><ref name="konventcv">{{cite web|url=http://www.konvent.gv.at/K/ZS/DE/PAD_17148/pad_17148.shtml| title=Dr. Dr. h.c. Karl Korinek| website=Österreich-Konvent| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref>
Effective May 2008, Korinek retired from the court, citing health reasons.<ref name="dirigent"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wienerzeitung.at/nachrichten/oesterreich/politik/261430_Das-Rennen-ist-eroeffnet.html| title=Das Rennen ist eröffnet| website=[[Wiener Zeitung]]| date=April 1, 2008| accessdate=2018-06-07| last=Hämmerle | first=Walter}}</ref>
Over the course of his career, Korinek wrote several books and more than 250 scholarly articles.<ref name="danubecv"/><ref name="staatsoper"/><ref name="ggeab"/>
== Death and legacy ==
Korinek died on March 9, 2017, after a protracted struggle with heart disease.<ref name="staatsoper"/><ref name="vfghcv">{{cite web|url=https://www.vfgh.gv.at/medien/Karl_Korinek_%281940-2017%29__Eine_Stimme_fuer_den_Recht.de.html| title=Karl Korinek (1940–2017): Eine Stimme für den Rechtsstaat| website=[[Constitutional Court (Austria)|Austrian Constitutional Court]]| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref>
Korinek is acknowledged as having been one of the Constitutional Court's most influential members during his tenure; he may in fact have been one of the court's most influential members in the institution's entire history.<ref name="vfghcv"/> Even before he was appointed president of the court, Korinek has had more impact on the court's jurisprudence than would have been typical for a regular member.<ref name="tt">{{cite web| url=http://www.tt.com/home/10855001-91/karl-korinek-wird-75---und-will-nicht-mehr-%C3%B6ffentlich-schimpfen.csp| website=[[Tiroler Tageszeitung]]| title=Karl Korinek wird 75 - und will nicht mehr öffentlich schimpfen| date=December 12, 2015| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref name="orftrauer">{{cite web|url=http://wien.orf.at/news/stories/2830325/| title=Trauer nach Tod von Karl Korinek| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-07| website=[[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]]}}</ref> Commentators credit Korinek with having played a significant role in modernizing the tribunal's jurisprudence on constitutional rights questions;<ref name="jahresbericht">{{cite web|url=https://www.wu.ac.at/fileadmin/wu/h/structure/about/publications/JB/jahresbericht2005.pdf| title=Jahresbericht der Wirtschaftsuniversität Wien 2005| accessdate=2018-06-06| website=[[Vienna University of Economics and Business]]}}</ref> the court itself agrees.<ref name="vfghcv"/> Korinek is also credited for the fact that the court, under his leadership, has softened its traditional commitment to [[judicial restraint]] and has grown more assertive, protecting [[human rights]] principles more energetically and striking down laws more often.<ref name="quart"/>
Korinek has also been noted for his impact as an educator. Commentators have called him "one of the greats" of Austrian legal instruction.<ref name="dirigent"/><ref name="tt"/><ref name="kleine">{{cite web|url=https://www.kleinezeitung.at/politik/innenpolitik/5181341/Nach-Herzleiden_Frueherer-VfGHPraesident-Karl-Korinek-76-gestorben| title=Früherer VfGH-Präsident Karl Korinek (76) gestorben| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-07| website=[[Kleine Zeitung]]}}</ref> Korinek is said to have played a prominent role in shaping the minds of several generations of Austrian jurists.<ref name="unigraz">{{cite web|url=https://rewi.uni-graz.at/de/neuigkeiten/detail/article/karl-korinek/| title=Karl Korinek| website=[[University of Graz]]| date=March 14, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref>
He has been called the "doyen" of Austrian legal scholarship<ref name="wko">{{cite web|url=https://news.wko.at/news/oesterreich/Leitl:-Oesterreich-verliert-mit-Karl-Korinek-einen-grosse.html| title=Leitl: Österreich verliert mit Karl Korinek einen großen Staatsrechtler und wertvollen Menschen| website=[[Austrian Economic Chamber]]| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref> and one of the most distinguished personalities in the country's legal history.<ref name="orftrauer"/><ref name="kurier">{{cite web|url=https://kurier.at/politik/inland/frueherer-vfgh-praesident-karl-korinek-gestorben/251.042.329| title=Früherer VfGH-Präsident Karl Korinek gestorben| website=[[Kurier]]| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oeaw.ac.at/oesterreichische-akademie-der-wissenschaften/die-oeaw/article/verfassungsrechtler-karl-korinek-gestorben/| title=Verfassungsrechtler Karl Korinek gestorben| website=[[Austrian Academy of Sciences]]| date=March 13, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-08}}</ref>
== Politics ==
[[File:Gruppenfoto VfGH 2007.jpg|thumb|right|The Austrian Constitutional Court in June 2007; Karl Korinek is seated front row center]] Korinek was regarded as a committed conservative. Like his father before him, he joined the [[Austrian People's Party]]; he remained a card-carrying supporter when he was appointed to the Constitutional Court and only withdrew from membership when he was promoted to president.<ref name="dirigent"/><ref name="tt"/> He also was a member of the [[Cartellverband]].<ref name="oecvcv"/>
Throughout his life, Korinek remained a devout [[Catholic Church|Catholic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.katholisch.at/aktuelles/2017/03/15/karl-korinek-war-vorbild-als-jurist-und-christ| title=Karl Korinek war Vorbild als Jurist und Christ| website=[[Catholic Church in Austria]]| date=March 15, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-08}}</ref> He was active in the Vienna Catholic Academy ({{lang|de|Wiener katholische Akademie}}) and in the Association of Catholic Graduates ({{lang|de|katholischer Akademikerverband}}).<ref name="quart"/> Korinek credited his [[Christianity]] in general and [[Thomas Aquinas]] in particular with having materially influenced his legal philosophy.<ref name="kirchennet">{{cite web|url=http://www.kirchen.net/kbw_intern/section.asp?sec=17&menuopt=archiv&apid=5208| title=Karl Korinek: Der Verfassungsgerichtshof-Präsident in Salzburg bei der Thomas-Feier| website=kirchen.net| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref>
Korinek's promotion to president of the Constitutional Court was part of an attempt by then-[[Chancellor of Austria|Chancellor]] [[Wolfgang Schüssel]] to move the court to the right.<ref name="news">{{cite web|url=https://www.news.at/a/regierung-verfassungsgerichtshof-linie-15343| title=Regierung will Verfassungsgerichtshof auf Linie bringen| website=[[NEWS (Austrian magazine)|NEWS]]| date=June 2, 2001| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> His outspoken conservatism and the circumstances of his promotion nonwithstanding, Korinek quickly acquired a reputation for integrity and non-partisan jurisprudence; he came to be widely respected across party lines.<ref name="kurier"/><ref name="kleine"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gruene.at/ots/glawischnig-mit-karl-korinek-verliert-oesterreich-einen-vordenker-fuer-die-modernisierung-der-verfassung| title=Glawischnig: Mit Karl Korinek verliert Österreich einen Vordenker für die Modernisierung der Verfassung| website=[[The Greens – The Green Alternative|The Greens]]| date=March 10, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-08}}</ref> During Korinek's tenure as its president, the Constitutional Court overturned several key pieces of Schüssel's legislative agenda. Also during Korinek's presidency, the court sided with [[Slovenes|Slovenian]] minority right activists in the {{lang|de|Ortstafelstreit}}, a long-running dispute about Slovenian language rights that [[Jörg Haider]]'s [[Austrian Freedom Party|Freedom Party]] had been using to stoke populist resentment. The decision, easily the most controversial in the institution's history, earned Korinek Haider's and the Freedom Party's lasting enmity.<ref name="dirigent"/><ref name="tt"/><ref name="ooen">{{cite web|url=http://www.nachrichten.at/nachrichten/politik/innenpolitik/Trauer-um-Spitzenjuristen-Karl-Korinek;art385,2507712| title=Trauer um Spitzenjuristen Karl Korinek| website=[[Oberösterreichische Nachrichten]]| date=March 11, 2017| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref>
Korinek became known for a number of signature positions that received praise from both sides of the political spectrum. He advocated for transparency in government, called for an overhaul of Austria's outsized and convoluted constitution, and demanded that legislators put craftsmanship before ideology in drafting statutes.<ref name="dirigent"/><ref name="tt"/><ref name="kurier"/> He also took a firm stance against government encroachments on constitutional rights. After his retirement, he became a vocal critic of online surveillance, especially of government-mandated online [[data retention]].<ref name="tt"/><ref name="falter">{{cite web|url=https://www.falter.at/archiv/FALTER_200711071704380010/karl-korinek| title=Hero der Woche: Karl Korinek| website=[[Falter]]| date=November 7, 2007| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref name="bigbrother">{{cite web|url=http://www.bigbrotherawards.at/2007/Preistraeger| title=Preisträger − Big Brother Awards 2007| website=[[Big Brother Awards]] Austria| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> His criticism of Austria's data retention program proved well founded when, in 2014, the [[European Court of Justice]] declared it illegal under European [[human rights]] rules.<ref name="ooen"/>
Korinek supported [[Andreas Khol]] in the [[Austrian presidential election, 2016|2016 Austrian presidential election]].<ref name="kleine"/><ref name="kurier"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://derstandard.at/2000033042316/Khols-Buergerkomitee-mit-Schuessel-Hengstschlaeger-und-Korinek| title=Khols Bürgerkomitee mit Schüssel, Hengstschläger und Korinek| website=[[Der Standard]]| date=March 16, 2016| accessdate=2018-06-08}}</ref>
== Personal life ==
Korinek was married for most of his adult life. He was survived by two children.<ref name="danubecv"/>
Korinek was passionate about music.<ref name="kurier"/> He sang in the [[Vienna State Opera]] choir in his student days; he remained involved in State Opera life throughout his career and well into retirement.<ref name="staatsoper"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opernfreunde.at/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Stretta_April2017_WEB.pdf| title=Im Gedenken an unseren ehemaligen Präsidenten Karli Korinek| website=Freunde der Wiener Staatsoper| date=April 2017| accessdate=2018-06-08}}</ref> Starting in 1999, he served on the board of directors of the opera, one of a handful of positions he did not retire from even when he was made the president of the Constitutional Court.<ref name="oecvcv"/><ref name="ggeab"/><ref name="kurier"/> Korinek authored books on the relationship between government and the arts, on [[Joseph Haydn]], and on the {{lang|de|[[Der Rosenkavalier]]}}, a comic opera by [[Richard Strauss]].<ref name="kurier"/> In an interview, Korinek compared the work of a legislator to that of a composer: both are striving to combine clarity with harmony, a parallel that Korinek claimed used to be widely discussed and acknowledged in the past.<ref name="komposition">{{cite web|url=https://diepresse.com/home/spectrum/literatur/379681/Komposition-in-Paragrafen| archive-url=https://archive.is/m502| archive-date=2012-07-12| title=Komposition in Paragrafen| last=Ferk | first=Janko| website=[[Die Presse]]| date=April 25, 2008| accessdate=2018-06-07}}</ref>
Korinek also published a book on the life and times of [[Julius Raab]], which became a local bestseller.<ref name="komposition"/>
== Selected awards ==
* 2000: [[Order of St. Sylvester|Knight's Grand Cross of the Order of St. Sylvester]]<ref name="news"/> * 2001: [[Decoration of Honour for Services to the Republic of Austria|Grand Decoration of Honor in Silver with Sash for Services to the Republic of Austria]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wienerzeitung.at/nachrichten/oesterreich/politik/195907_Korinek-erhielt-Auszeichnung.html| title=Korinek erhielt Auszeichnung| website=[[Wiener Zeitung]]| date=April 7, 2015| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> * 2003: Honorary Doctorate of the [[University of Salzburg]]<ref name="danubecv"/><ref name="vfghcv"/><ref name="kirchennet"/> * 2005: Honorary Doctorate of the [[Vienna University of Economics and Business]]<ref name="danubecv"/><ref name="jahresbericht"/> * 2006: Honorary Doctorate of the [[University of Graz]]<ref name="danubecv"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://archiv.uni-graz.at/de/geschichte/ehrendoktoren/| title=Ehrendoktoren| website=[[University of Graz]]| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> * 2006: Commander's Cross with Star of the Decoration of Honor for Services to the State of [[Lower Austria]]<ref name="komturkreuz"/> * 2006: Grand Decoration of Honor in Gold with Star for Services to the State of [[Styria]]<ref name="steirische"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.verwaltung.steiermark.at/cms/beitrag/11682627/74838276/_1| title=Groß Gold Stern für Präsident Korinek| website=[[Styria|Land Steiermark]]| date=August 30, 2006| accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> * 2006: [[Decoration of Honour for Services to the Republic of Austria|Grand Decoration of Honor in Gold with Sash for Services to the Republic of Austria]]<ref name="ggeab"/> * 2007: Defensor Libertatis Award of the Austrian [[Big Brother Awards]]<ref name="bigbrother"/> * 2007: [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany|Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany with Star and Sash]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bundesverfassungsgericht.de/SharedDocs/Pressemitteilungen/DE/2007/bvg07-074.html| title=Besuch einer Delegation des österreichischen Verfassungsgerichtshofs beim Bundesverfassungsgericht| date=July 4, 2007| accessdate=2018-06-06| website=[[Federal Constitutional Court]]}}</ref> * 2015: [[Theodor Innitzer|Cardinal Innitzer Award]] for Scholarly Achievement of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vienna]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.erzdioezese-wien.at/site/home/nachrichten/article/46649.html| title=Innitzer-Preis 2015 geht an früheren VfGH-Präsidenten Korinek| date=November 16, 2015| accessdate=2018-06-06| website=[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vienna]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://derstandard.at/2000025807447/Ehemaliger-VfGH-Praesident-Korinek-erhaelt-Innitzer-Preis-2015| title=Ehemaliger VfGH-Präsident Korinek erhält Innitzer-Preis| date=November 16, 2015| accessdate=2018-06-07| website=[[Der Standard]]}}</ref>
== Selected publications ==
=== Legal ===
* {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1970| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| title=Wirtschaftliche Selbstverwaltung: eine rechtswissenschaftliche Untersuchung am Beispiel der österreichischen Rechtsordnung| publisher=Springer| place=Vienna}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1971| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Verfassungsrechtliche Aspekte der Raumplanung: verfassungsrechtliche und rechtspolitische Gedanken zu Planungsrecht und Eigentumsschutz| publisher=Österreichisches Institut für Mittelstandspolitik| place=Linz}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1981| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| author-last2=Müller| author-first2=Jörg Paul| author-last3=Schlaich| author-first3=Klaus| title=Die Verfassungsgerichtsbarkeit im Gefüge der Staatsfunktionen| publisher=de Gruyter| place=Berlin, New York| isbn=978-3-11-008614-0}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1982| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Grundfragen des Wirtschaftslenkungsrechts| publisher=Orac| place=Vienna| isbn=3-853-68505-6}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1986| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Die Kontrolle wirtschaftlicher Unternehmungen durch den Rechnungshof| publisher=Orac| place=Vienna| isbn=3-853-68728-8}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1992| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title= Entwicklungstendenzen in der Grundrechtsjudikatur des Verfassungsgerichtshofes: Vortrag, gehalten vor der Niederösterreichischen Juristischen Gesellschaft in St. Pölten am 20. November 1991| publisher=Orac| place=Vienna| isbn=3-700-70335-X }} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1993| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Grundlagen staatlicher Privatwirtschaftsverwaltung: verfassungsrechtliche und einfachgesetzliche Rahmenbedingungen nicht hoheitlicher Verwaltung| publisher=Leykam| place=Graz| isbn=3-701-18965-X}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=1999| editor-last1=Korinek| editor-first1=Karl| editor-last2=Holoubek| editor-first2=Michael| editor-mask=1| title=Österreichisches Bundesverfassungsrecht: Textsammlung und Kommentar| publisher=Springer| place=Vienna| isbn=3-211-83222-X}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=2000| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Grundrechte und Verfassungsgerichtsbarkeit| publisher=Springer| place=Vienna| isbn=3-211-83568-7}}
=== Other ===
* {{cite book| ref=harv| date=2005| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| title=Der Onkel Julius oder Der Wiederaufbau Österreichs in Anekdoten| publisher=Manz| place=Vienna| isbn=3-214-00645-2}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=2006| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Staat und Kunst| publisher=Schöningh| place=Paderborn| isbn=3-506-72958-6}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=2009| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Joseph Haydn - Erneuerung und Vollendung: eine Annäherung in fünf Essays| publisher=Manz| place=Vienna| isbn=978-3-214-00694-5}} * {{cite book| ref=harv| date=2012| author-last1=Korinek| author-first1=Karl| author-mask=1| title=Der Rosenkavalier. {{one source|section|date=May 2015}} '''Ljubo Boban''' (10 May 1933 – 9 October 1994) was a Croatian historian and academic.
He was born in [[Solin, Croatia|Solin]]. At the [[University of Zagreb]]'s [[Faculty of Philosophy, Zagreb|Faculty of Philosophy]], he graduated and later obtained a PhD degree in 1964 with a thesis on the 1939 [[Cvetković–Maček Agreement]]. He became professor at the same faculty in 1975. In 1986 he became full member of the [[Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] and in 1991 he was made member of its presidency.
Boban died of a [[heart attack]] in Zagreb on 9 October 1994.
==Sources== *[http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/52568 Ljubo Boban (1933-1994)]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} '''Lynette Ramsay Silver''' {{postnominals|country=AUS|size=100%|sep=,|OAM|DFC}} (born 1945) is an Australian historian and author. She has written a number of books dealing with Australian history. In particular many of her works deal with military history.
==Career== Her first book published in 1986, "A Fool's Gold?", deals with the first discoveries of payable gold in Australia and was written after she discovered archival documents "lost" for 134 years. Her next book, "The Battle of Vinegar Hill", first published in 1989, is the first (and only) full account of the Irish insurrection [[Castle Hill convict rebellion]] of 1804. "Sandakan - A Conspiracy of Silence", released in 1998, uncovered the fate of 2428 Australian and British prisoners of war who died at the Sandakan POW Camp in Borneo or on one of the infamous death marches, and investigated the coverup of a failed rescue mission [[Operation Kingfisher (World War II)]]. In 2004 "The Bridge at Parit Sulong", is an investigation into the mass murder of prisoners of war by Japanese soldiers in Malaya in 1942. [[Parit Sulong Massacre|massacre of allied prisoners]]. Further books, mainly related to military history, followed.
==Personal life== She is married and has two children and three grandchildren.
==Books== *A Fool's Gold? (1986) * The Battle of Vinegar Hill (1989) * The Heroes of Rimau: Unravelling the Mystery of One of World War II's Most Daring Raids (1990) * Krait; The fishing boat that went to war (1992) * Pot Pourri and other Secrets from the Garden (1992) * My Ballet Book (1992) * Making...Friendship Bands(1994) * Flowercraft (1995) * Papercraft: Paper-Making & Paper-MacHe (1995) * Playing skipping and Elastic Games (1995) * Fabulous furphies; Ten great myths form Australia's past (1997) * Sandakan: A Conspiracy of Silence (1998) * On This Rock: The Church of St Peter Hornsby 1898-1998 (1998) * Great Kids Games (1999) * The Bridge at Parit Sulong (2004) * Marcel Caux - A Life Unravelled (2005) * Deadly Secrets: The Singapore Raids 1943-45 (2010) * Blood Brothers (2010) * In The Mouth Of The Tiger (2014) * Billy: My Life as a Teenage POW (2016)

{{Infobox building |name=Manial Palace|image=A Room in Mohamed ali Palace.jpg |caption=The main facade of the Palace. |location_town=Manial
[[Cairo]] |location_country= {{Flag|Egypt}} |coordinates = {{coord|30.0274|31.2298|format=dms|region:EG_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |map_type = Egypt |architect= |client= [[Mohammed Ali Tewfik]] |engineer= |construction_start_date=1875 |date_demolished= |cost= |structural_system= |architectural_style= [[Arabic]], [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]], [[Moorish]] |size= }} [[File:GD-EG-Caire-AlManyal021.JPG|250px|thumb|Manial Palace, entry [[porte cochere]] and gardens.]] [[File:GD-EG-Caire-AlManyal026.JPG|250px|thumb|Manial Palace, the throne room of [[Mohammed Ali Tewfik]].]] The '''Manial Palace and Museum''', is a former [[Muhammad Ali dynasty|Alawiyya dynasty]] era [[palace]] and grounds on [[Rhoda Island]] on the [[Nile]]. It is located in the Sharia Al-Saray area in the [[El-Manial]] district of southern [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]]. The palace and estate has been preserved as an Antiquities Council directed [[historic house museum]] and estate, reflecting the settings and lifestyle of the late 19th- and early 20th-century Egyptian royal prince and heir apparent. The residence compound, composed of five separate and distinctively styled buildings, is surrounded by [[Persian garden]]s within an extensive [[English garden|English Landscape garden]] estate park, along a small branch of the Nile. ==History== The Manial Palace was built by Prince [[Mohammed Ali Tewfik]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.sca-egypt.org/eng/MUS_Manial-Palace.htm|title=Supreme Council of Antiquities - Museums|website=www.sca-egypt.org|access-date=2018-03-14}} (1875—1955), the uncle of King Farouk, between 1899 and 1929. He had it designed in a style integrating European [[Art Nouveau]] and [[Rococo]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.sca-egypt.org/eng/MUS_Manial-Palace.htm|title=Supreme Council of Antiquities - Museums|website=www.sca-egypt.org|access-date=2018-03-14}} with many traditional [[Islamic architecture]] styles including [[Ottoman architecture|Ottoman]], [[Moorish Revival architecture|Moorish]], [[Persian architecture|Persian]], creating inspired combinations in spatial design, architectural and interior decorations, and sumptuous materials.{{Cite web|url=http://touregypt.net/manial.htm/|title=Egypt: Cairo: Other - The Manial Palace|website=touregypt.net|language=ru|access-date=2018-03-14}} It housed his extensive art, furniture, clothing, silver, objets d'art collections, and [[medieval]] [[manuscript]]s{{Cite news|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/egypt/cairo/sights/museums-galleries/manial-palace|title=Manial Palace in Cairo, Egypt|last=Planet|first=Lonely|work=Lonely Planet|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en}} dating back to the Middle Ages. The ceramic tile work of the entryway and the mosque were created by the Armenian ceramist [[David Ohannessian]], originally from Kutahya. ==Museum== {{commonscat|Al-Manyal Palace Museum}} The Palace, furnishings, and Prince's collections were given to the Egyptian [[Supreme Council of Antiquities]] in 1955. The Manial Palace and estate are a public art and history museum, with historical gardens, and forested nature park. There is also Hunting Lodge Museum, that belonged to the late [[King Farouk]]. === Prince Muhammad Ali Palace (Manial Palace) === File:غرفة العرش بقصر محمد على بالمنيل.jpg File:The Golden Room.jpg File:قاعة العرش بقصر الامير محمد على بالقاهره.jpg File:Cairo2015ManialPalastThroneHall.jpg| File:Nice Room.jpg File:قصر محمد علي.jpg| File:غرفة الاستقبال بقصر محمد على بالقاهره.jpg| File:القاعه الشتوية بقصر محمد على بالقاهره.jpg File:Manial Palace and Museum 0.jpg File:The spacious room.jpg File:Manial Palace and Museum.jpg File:Cairo2015ManialPalastClockTower.jpg File:برج الساعة.jpg File:Cairo2015ManialResidencePalast.jpg File:Cairo2015ManialPalastMirrorsHall.jpg File:Cairo2015ManialResidencePalaceReception.jpg File:Cairo2015ManialPalastMosque.jpg File:CairoManialPalastEntrance.jpg File:المشربية.jpg File:A Room in Mohamed ali Palace.jpg File:Launch room in Mohamed ali palace.jpg File:الغرفة الذهبية فى قصر الامير محمد على المنيل.jpg File:A room in Mohamed ali Palace.jpg File:Mohamed ali palace.jpg File:Mohamed ali mosque in Manial.jpg File:Mohamed Ali's Mosque, Cairo, Egypt.jpg File:طريق جنة الاشجار.jpg| File:من داخل قصر الامير محمد علي بالمنيل.jpg File:قصر الامير محمد علي بالمنيل.jpg File:قاعة بقصر الامير محمد علي.jpg File:داخل قصر الامير محمد علي بالمنيل.jpg ==See also== *[[Muhammad Ali Dynasty]] *[[Old Cairo]] - '''Nenad Petrović''' ([[Serbian language|Serbian]] [[Cyrillic]]: Ненад Петровић) (30 May 1925 – 21 March 2014)<ref>[http://www.ebritic.com/?p=316447]</ref><ref>[http://www.ljudigovore.com/2014/03/na-vest-o-smrti-knjizevnika-nenada-v-petorovica/]</ref> was a Serbian writer, and one of numerous [[displaced person]]s after [[World War II]] and [[Communism|revolution]] in [[Yugoslavia]].
==Life== Petrović was born in 1925 in [[Zagreb]] and graduated from [[Belgrade]]'s [[Grande école]] (Velika škola) in 1944, when he joined the national resistance movement, General [[Dragoljub Mihailović]]'s loyal [[Chetniks]], while under [[Axis Powers|Axis]] occupation.
After withdrawing through [[Sandzak]] and [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]] in 1944 and 1945, he became an interpreter for the [[Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] units serving the [[British Army]] in [[Italy]] and [[Germany]]. In 1947, he came to [[Great Britain]] as a [[Displaced Person]] and first worked as a farm hand and later as an employee in an industrial concern. He studied [[Political Economy]] in [[London]].
Petrović was active in the association ''Oslobodjenje'' (Liberation) and was a member of the editorial board of the publication, ''Naša Reć'' (Our Word) from 1958 and of the editorial board of the publishing house ''Naše Delo'' (Our Deed).
From 1963, he was secretary of the exile ''Committee of the [[Liberal International]]''. He was a member of [[Democratic Alternative (Serbia)|Democratic Alternative]], founded by [[Desimir Tošić]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eastethnia.blogspot.com/2008/02/in-memory-of-desimir-toi.html |title=East Ethnia: In memory of Desimir Tošić |publisher=Eastethnia.blogspot.com |date=2008-02-09 |accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/serbian/news/2008/02/080208_tosic.shtml |title=BBCSerbian.com | News | Umro Desimir Tošić |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref> He is also secretary of the ''Association of Serbian Writers and Artists in Exile''.
Petrović was active in the work of the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]]. Under the editorship of Professor [[Radoje Knežević]] he was, from 1964 to 1974, permanent correspondent of ''Glas kanadskih Srba'' (Voice of the Canadian Serbs).
==Works== Petrović has published in [[English language|English]] in the ''Review of the Study Centre for Yugoslav Affairs'', articles ''Yugoslav Communist Party Congresses since. the War'' and ''The Fall of [[Aleksandar Rankovic|Alexander Rankovic]]'' and in the Serbian language, among others, articles on [[Dimitrije Mitrinović]] (1967), ''The Centenary of [[Lenin]]'s Birth'', [[Vladimir Gacinovic]], Risto Radulovic, [[Peter Bergardovich Struve|Peter Struve]].
He has published the following books: ''The Two Faces of Jugoslav Communism'' (1963) and ''The Daughter of [[Marx]]'' (1973), a critical survey of the beginnings of [[Socialism]] in [[England]]. He has contributed to the two volumes, ''Democratic Jugoslavia'', articles entitled: "For a new social and political morality" (1967) and "The awakening of nationalism under Communist regimes" (1972); in both editions of the selected works of the ''Association of Serbian Writers and Artists in Exile'' on: "Our literature in exile" (1973) and "The latest monograph on [[Hilandar]]" (1980). In the record of Twenty years of work and political attitudes of the Association ''Oslobodjenje'' Petrovic contributed an article entitled: "In Emigration — yet independent of it."
In [[Belgrade]] he has published: ''Iz života londonskih političkih emigracija'' (From the life of the London Political emigrants) (1998) and ''Ogled o smislu i zabludama'' (Essay on Sense and Aberrations, 2001).

[[Image:Packet Schooner.jpg|thumb|175px|upright|1793 newspaper ad for a packet schooner, [[Chestertown, Maryland]]]]
'''Packet boats''' were medium-sized boats designed for domestic mail, passenger, and freight transportation in European countries and their [[Colony|colonies]], including North American rivers and canals. They were used extensively during the 18th and 19th centuries and featured regularly scheduled service.
When such ships were put into use in the 18th century on the [[Atlantic Ocean]] between [[Kingdom of Great Britain|Great Britain]] and its colonies, the services were called the [[packet trade]].
==History== Packet craft were used extensively in European coastal mail services since the 17th century, and gradually added cramped passenger accommodation. As early as 1629, the [[Dutch East India Company]] was carrying some passengers on the ill-fated ''[[Batavia (ship)|Batavia]]'' from [[Texel]] in Holland to [[Java]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://museum.wa.gov.au/research/research-areas/maritime-archaeology/batavia-cape-inscription/batavia | title=Batavia's History | publisher=Government of Western Australia | accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref> Later, scheduled services were offered, but the time journeys took depended much on the weather. They are even found to be a subject of [[Daniel Defoe]]'s 1724 novel ''[[Roxana: The Fortunate Mistress]]''.<ref>The novel contains numerous references to packet boats, and includes a section entitled "[https://books.google.com/books?id=ObM6AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA113 Sail in packet-boat to Rotterdam]".</ref> In England the King maintained a weekly packet service with the continent and Ireland using 15 packet vessels.<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=rNCUMoRsikMC&pg=A120 A Collection of Voyages and Travels, consisting of Authentic Writers in our own Tongue, which have not before been collected in English, or have only been abridged in other Collections]'' Vol I., 1745, p.120</ref> Their importance was evident in the [[Rose Hill Packet]] becoming the first craft built in the colony of New South Wales in 1789.
Over the two centuries of the sailing packet craft development, they came in various rig configurations which included: [[schooner]]s, [[Hermaphrodite brig|schooners-brigs]], [[sloop]]s, [[Cutter (boat)|cutters]], [[brig]]s, [[brigantine]]s, [[lugger]]s, [[felucca]]s, [[galley]]s, [[xebec]]s, [[barque]]s and their ultimate development in the [[clipper|clipper ships]]. Earlier they were also known as [[dispatch boats]], but the service was also provided by privateers during time of war, and on occasion chartered private yachts. News of "record passages" was eagerly awaited by the public, and the craft's captain and crew were often celebrated in the press. Behind this search for [[sailing faster than the wind]] however lay the foundations for a development in naval architecture and its science which would serve until the appearance of the steam vessels.
In 1863, during the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], the packet boat ''Marshall'' carried the body of Confederate General [[Stonewall Jackson]] from [[Lynchburg, Virginia|Lynchburg]] to his home in [[Lexington, Virginia]] for burial.<ref>[http://www.civilwarnews.com/archive/articles/packetboat.htm Deborah Fitts, "Hull of Packet Boat That Carried Jackson's Body Is Protected"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907230730/http://www.civilwarnews.com/archive/articles/packetboat.htm |date=2008-09-07 }}, Civil War News, Jan 2007, accessed 22 Nov 2008</ref>
===Canal packet boats=== The American canal packet boats were typically narrow (about 14 feet) to accommodate canals, but might be 70–90 feet long. When the [[Erie Canal]] opened in New York state in 1825 along the [[Mohawk River]], demand quickly rose for travelers to be accommodated. Canal packet boats included cabin space for up to 60 passengers. Unlike European and American sailing vessels, that sought to attain greater speed under sail, the canal packet boats were drawn through the Erie Canal by teams of two or three horses or mules. Compared to overland travel, the boats cut journey time in half and were much more comfortable. Travelers could get from New York City to Buffalo in ten days, with a combination of sailing and packet boats. Some passengers took the boats to see both the Erie Canal and the natural landscapes. Significantly, thousands of others used packet boats to emigrate to [[Ohio]] and other parts of the [[Midwest]]. These boats were also instrumental in the settling of and travel within [[Upstate New York]] through the branch canals such as the [[Chenango Canal]]. Packet boats were also popular along the [[James River and Kanawha Canal]] in Virginia, allowing travel beyond the falls upriver.
==Mail steamer== {{see also|J. W. Westcott II}} [[File:18th-century packet boat used for postal service.jpg|thumb|An 1825 book plate depicting a typical packet boat]]
''Mail steamers'' were [[steamship]]s which carried the mail across waterways, such as across an ocean or between islands, primarily during the 19th century and early 20th century, when the cost of sending a letter was declining to the point an ordinary person could afford the cost of sending a letter across great distances. In addition to carrying mail, most mail steamers carried passengers or cargo since the revenue from the mail service, if any, was insufficient by itself to pay for the cost of its travel.
However, the advantage for a steamship carrying mail was that its arrival would be advertised in advance in the newspapers, thus giving it "free advertising" as a travel option for passengers or cargo. In most cases, mail carried by mail steamers was delivered to the post office to which it was addressed. In some cases, the incoming mail would be advertised in the local newspaper for pickup at the post office or at the steamship's office for a fee, if not already fee-paid.
Occasionally, because of political instability when a post office could not provide normal services, incoming mail from a mail steamer would be delivered to a local delivery service, which would deliver the mail and charge the addressee an extra fee for the service. When this occurred, the local delivery service would place its own local service stamp or mark on the envelope when the extra fee was paid.
=== Universal Postal Union regulations ===
Mail carried by these steamers – sometimes known as paquebot mail – was subject to various regulations by the governments involved as well as the [[Universal Postal Union]]'s (UPU) regulations stated at the UPU [[Vienna]] Conference of 1891.
==Aircraft namesake== The [[Fairchild C-82 Packet|C-82 Packet]] twin-engined, twin-boom cargo aircraft designed and built by Fairchild Aircraft was named as a tribute to the packet boat.{{cn|date=July 2018}} It was used by the United States Army Air Forces and the successor United States Air Force following World War II.

[[Academician]] of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] | thesis_title = Church and state in Geneva of the 16th century in the era of Calvinism | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | prizes = }} '''Robert Yuryevich Wipper''' ({{lang-ru|Роберт Юрьевич Виппер}}, {{lang-lv|Roberts Vipers}}; {{OldStyleDate|14 July|1859|2 July}} – 30 December 1954) was a Russian, Latvian and [[Soviet]] historian of [[classical antiquity]], medieval and modern period. ==Biography== Born in [[Moscow]], Wipper graduated from the faculty of history and philology at the [[Moscow University]] in 1880.{{cite web | url =http://letopis.msu.ru/peoples/685|title=Виппер Роберт Юрьевич (Георгиевич) |publisher=[[Moscow University]]| language=Russian| accessdate =13 June 2015}} In 1894, he had become the Doctor of General History and in 1901–1919 was the Professor in Ordinary of the Department of General History. He later attained the professorship. Wipper lectured the history of prehistoric culture, the history of the Ancient East, Greece, the Roman Republic and the Roman Empire, as well as social ideas and the methodology of history. He also authored several historical textbooks. Having emigrated to Latvia, he taught at the [[University of Latvia]] until 1940 when the country was incorporated into the Soviet Union as the [[Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic]]. Wipper's works received the privilege of translation into English for foreign readership. In 1922, Wipper published a book about [[Ivan the Terrible]]. A revised edition of it, published in 1942, was welcomed by Soviet reviewers. In 1944, Wipper received the [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] and the [[Order of Lenin]] in 1945. He also became a member of the [[Soviet Academy of Sciences]]. Until his death Wipper supported the [[Christ myth theory]].{{cite web | url =http://pstgu.ru/download/1430825026.5_andreev_73-88.pdf |title=Дискуссия об историчности Иисуса Христа в советском религиоведении|author=А. В. Андреев|work=Вестник ПСТГУ|language=Russian| date=2015| accessdate =13 June 2015}} The first edition of the ''[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]]'' characterised him as "the most talented representative in historical science of the Russian [[petty bourgeois]] [[intelligentsiya]]".{{cite book | editor=Thomas Riha| title =Readings in Russian Civilization, Volume 1: Russia Before Peter the Great, 900-1700| publisher =University of Chicago Press| year =2009| page =98| isbn =0226718433}} He died in Moscow at the age of 95. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book| author = | chapter = | chapter-url = | format = | url = | title =Imperial Moscow University: 1755-1917: encyclopedic dictionary | orig-year = | agency = A. Andreev, D. Tsygankov | edition = |location= Moscow |year= 2010 |publisher= Russian political encyclopedia (ROSSPEN) |at= |volume= |issue = | pages =129—130 | page = | series = | isbn = 978-5-8243-1429-8| ref =Imperial Moscow University}} {{Christ myth theory|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wipper, Robert}} [[Category:1859 births]] [[Category:1954 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century historians]] [[Category:Christ myth theory proponents]] [[Category:Full Members of the USSR Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Latvian historians]] [[Category:Moscow State University alumni]] [[Category:People from Moscow]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Soviet historians]] [[Category:Professorships at the Imperial Moscow University]]

[[Jack Pfefer]], godfather{{cite book | last = Hornbaker | first = Tim | title = National Wrestling Alliance: The Untold Story of the Monopoly That Strangled Pro Wrestling | publisher = ECW Press | year = 2007 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1550227413| page = 252 pp}} |billed = |trainer = [[Stu Hart]] |debut = 1985{{cite web |url= http://wrestlingdata.com/index.php?befehl=bios&wrestler=3229&bild=1&details=7|title= Ross Hart: General Information|publisher=wrestlingdata.com}} |retired = 2005{{cite web |url= http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=6370&page=3|title= Ross Hart: Career highlights|publisher=cagematch.net}} }} '''Ross Lindsay Hart''', (born January 3, 1960){{cite book|title=[[Pain and Passion: The History of Stampede Wrestling]]|last=McCoy|first=Heath|page=33|year=2007|publisher=[[ECW Press]]|isbn=978-1-55022-787-1}} is a Canadian-American retired [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], promoter,http://www.espn.com/magazine/assael_20021118.html trainer, booker, TV producer, coach and actor. Hart is a member of the [[Hart wrestling family]] and the second youngest son of [[Stu Hart|Stu]] and Helen Hart. He is best known for his work in [[Stampede Wrestling]] and several appearances in [[WWE]], often with his siblings [[Bruce Hart (wrestler)|Bruce]], [[Keith Hart (wrestler)|Keith]], [[Bret Hart|Bret]], [[Diana Hart|Diana]] and [[Owen Hart]]. ==Early life== Hart is of Irish descent through his maternal grandfather and [[Greeks|Greek]] descent through his maternal grandmother.{{cite book | last = Hart | first = Bret | authorlink = Bret Hart | title = Hitman: My real life in the cartoon world of wrestling | publisher = Ebury Press | year = 2007 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 9780091932862| page = 8 pp}}{{cite web|url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/columns/26902|title=Ask 411 - 5.07.02|accessdate=|author=Letawsky, Craig|authorlink=|date=2002-05-07|format=|work=|publisher=411wrestling.com|pages=|language=|quote=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117152505/http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/columns/26902|archivedate=2007-11-17|df=}}{{cite book | last = Hart | first = Diana | authorlink = Diana Hart |author2=McLellan, Kirstie | title = [[Under the Mat: Inside Wrestling's Greatest Family]] | publisher = [[Fenn]] | year = 2001 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 1-55168-256-7| page = 16 pp}}{{cite book | author = Heath McCoy | title = Pain and Passion: The History of Stampede Wrestling | publisher = ECWPress | year = 2007 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1-55022-787-1| page = 30 pp}} His father was mainly of [[Ulster Scots people|Scots-Irish]] descent but also had Scottish and English ancestry.{{cite book | authorlink = John Lister | title = Slamthology: Collected Wrestling Writings 1991-2004 | publisher = jnlister | year = 2005 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 1-4116-5329-7| page = 252 pp}}{{cite book | author = Heath McCoy | title = Pain and Passion: The History of Stampede Wrestling | publisher = ECWPress | year = 2007 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1-55022-787-1| page = 16 pp}} Hart is a dual citizen of Canada and the United States due to his mother Helen Hart being from New York.{{cite book | author1 = [[Martha Hart]] |author2= Eric Francis | title = Broken Harts: The Life and Death of Owen Hart |publisher = [[Rowman & Littlefield]] | year = 2004 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1-59077-036-8| page = 84 pp}}{{cite web |last=Hart|first=Bret|authorlink=Bret Hart|url= http://slam.canoe.com/SlamWrestlingBretHart9799/hitman_may17.html|title= An open letter to Shawn Michaels |date=May 17, 1997|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} Hart grew up in a [[Hart House (Alberta)|household]] with 11 siblings, [[Smith Hart|Smith]], [[Bruce Hart (wrestler)|Bruce]], [[Keith Hart (wrestler)|Keith]], [[Wayne Hart (wrestling)|Wayne]], [[Dean Hart|Dean]], Ellie, Georgia, [[Bret Hart|Bret]], Alison, [[Diana Hart|Diana]] and [[Owen Hart|Owen]].{{cite book | last = Wall | first = Karen L. | title = Game Plan: A Social History of Sports in Alberta | publisher = University of Alberta Press | year = 2012 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0888645944| page = 276 pp}} Hart's middle name was given to him in honor of his father's longtime friend [[Luther Lindsay]] and he was the godson of wrestler and promoter [[Jack Pfefer]].{{cite book | last = Hornbaker | first = Tim | title = National Wrestling Alliance: The Untold Story of the Monopoly That Strangled Pro Wrestling | publisher = ECW Press | year = 2007 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1550227413| page = 252 pp}} Hart has stated that his earliest memory is hearing his father Stu training wrestlers in their family basement, known as [[Hart Dungeon|The Dungeon]].{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/download/LoserLeavesTownPodcast11010WRossHart/loserleavestown011010.mp3|title=LoserLeavesTownPodcast: Ross Hart interview}} Hart's first experience working for his father's promotion [[Stampede Wrestling]] was selling programs for the shows when he was six years old. Hart is a childhood friend of fellow wrestler [[Milad Elzein]] who is the same age, he would sometimes help Hart sell the programs before the Stampede shows when they were young.{{cite web|url= http://canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingBios/wizal.html |title=Wrestling Canadian Hall of Fame: Abu Wizal|work=[[SLAM! Wrestling]]|author=[[Greg Oliver|Oliver, Greg]]|publisher=[[Canoe.ca|Canadian Online Explorer]]|accessdate=2016-04-02}} ==Professional wrestling career== ===In the ring=== ====Stampede Wrestling==== In the 80s Hart wrestled for the original Stampede Wrestling having matches with wrestlers such as Drago Zhivago,{{cite book|title=Pain and Passion: The History of Stampede Wrestling|last=McCoy|first=Heath|page=1|year=2007|publisher=[[ECW Press]]|isbn=978-1-55022-787-1}} Cuban Assassin, Gerry Morrow, Biff Wellington, Jude Rosenbloom, [[Chris Benoit]], Goldie Rogers, Steve Blackman, Steve DiSalvo, Vokhan Singh, Great Gama, Mike Hammer, Beef Wellington, Mr. Hito, Vladimir Krupoff, Adolph Barbee, George Skaaland and brother in-law BJ Annis.{{cite web |url=http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=6370&page=4|title= Ross Hart: Matches|publisher=cagematch.net}} Hart worked in tag team matches with Keiichi Yamada, Ken Johnson, George Skaaland and Johnny Smith as well as with his brothers Bruce against the Cuban Commandos. He participated in three-man tag team matches with his younger brother Owen and brother in-law Ben Bassarab against Drago Thomas, Gama Singh and Vladimir Krupoff as well. During this period he also took part in battle royales with many of the aforementioned wrestlers and competed for the Stampede British Commonwealth Mid-Heavyweight Championship. ====Sporadic work and appearances for WWF==== In the 80s Hart worked in the UK and wrestled on the program [[World of Sport (UK TV series)|World of Sport]] in singles matches against Marty Jones[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C_NstyiZNYU Marty Jones v Ross Hart (world of sport)] and in tag team matches with his brother [[Owen Hart|Owen]] against [[Fit Finlay]] and Rocky Moran,{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ldDJ4X9SJ4 | title=World Of Sport – Fit Finlay & Rocky Moran vs Owen Hart & Ross Hart}} they performed as faces.https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/05/5-owen-hart-matches-you-have-to-watch.html Ross and Owen toured most of Europe together in 1983.{{cite web| url=https://books.google.se/books?hl=sv&id=GDHYAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=ross+hart|year=2001|author=Meltzer, Dave|title=Tributes: Remembering Some of the World's Greatest Wrestlers|page=5}} Hart shortly worked for WWF in the 90's and appeared on the television program [[WWF Wrestling Challenge]] under the ring name Ross Lindsey.{{cite web|url=http://www.profightdb.com/wrestlers/ross-hart-7766.html |title=Ross Hart: Profile & Match Listing |website=profightdb.com |publisher= The Internet Wrestling Database}} During his time there he mostly wrestled Ted DiBiase in singles matches and tag teamed with Mike Pocari against The Orient Express, with Barry Hardy against Power And Glory or with Mike Morgan and Ron Cumberledge against Demolition. In 1994 hart worked for [[All Star Wrestling]] in England for a short period. He wrestled in victorious singles matches with Red Bronco, Johnny Angel, Duke Lynch, Count Von Zuppi, Drew McDonald. Duke Lynch being the only one he wrestled more than once. At the [[SummerSlam (1994)|1994 SummerSlam]] Hart can be seen attempting to climb the cage in which his brothers Bret and Owen Hart had their match together with other members of the Hart family.{{cite book | author = Ben Undelson | title = Fiction. A Nostalgic Guide to Growing up with the WWF | publisher = lulu.com | year = 2013 | location = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1-304-10190-7| page = 330 pp}}{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/2217881/wwe-news-ex-wife-of-british-bulldog-petitioning-for-his-induction-into-wwe-hall-of-fame/|title=WWE news: ex-wife of British Bulldog petitioning for his induction into WWE Hall Of Fame|author=Droste, Ryan|publisher=[[Inquisitr]]|date=July 3, 2015|accessdate=2016-04-06}} ====Return to Stampede Wrestling and Wrestlemania appearance==== Hart continued to wrestle sporadically for the 1999-2007 incarnation of Stampede Wrestling, having matches with wrestlers such as Rod Rage, Juggernaut, Cuban Assassin, Ryan Evans and Apocalypse before retiring in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/bios/r/ross-hart/ |title=Ross Hart|publisher=Online World Of Wrestling|accessdate=2015-04-02}} Hart appeared again for WWF ([[World Wrestling Entertainment#Name dispute|now renamed WWE]]) in an in ring capacity at [[WrestleMania XXVI]], where he was a lumberjack for his brother Bret's first WWE match in 13 years, a [[Hardcore wrestling|No Holds Barred]] [[Professional wrestling match types#Lumberjack match|Lumberjack match]] against the WWE chairman [[Vince McMahon]]. The storyline was that McMahon had paid off Ross and the rest of the Hart family to betray Bret, but all of them turned on him and helped Bret win the match.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/26/matches/13662452|title=Bret Hart def. Mr. McMahon in a No Holds Barred Match|date=March 28, 2010|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=December 23, 2012}} ===Promoting, booking and training=== Hart worked as a Television Producer on the original Stampede Wrestling. Hart together with his brother Bruce relaunched their father's Stampede Wrestling promotion in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://albertaventure.com/1999/07/stampede-wrestling-rides-again/ |title=Stampede Wrestling Rides Again|author=Gordon, Cope|website=albertaventure.com|archive-date=14 October 2014|archive-url=http://archive.is/S45mi|publisher=Alberta Venture|date=Jul 1, 1999|accessdate=2016-04-10}}{{cite web|url= http://slam.canoe.com/SlamWrestlingArchive/aug21_get.html |title=Get ready to rumble! Wrestling, That is|publisher=[[Richard Berger & Barking Spider Productions]]|year=2010|page=64-65}} In 2005 Hart worked as senior advisor and commissioner for Celtic Pro Wrestling in Ireland.{{cite web|url=http://411mania.com/wrestling/nate-stein-weekly-report-1012/|title=Nate Stein Weekly Report|website=411mania.com|date=October 12, 2005|accessdate=2016-04-11}}{{cite web|url=https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/CelticProWrestling/conversations/topics/12?var=1|title=Celtic Pro Tournament April 8th in Dublin|author=Gordon, Cope|website=groups.yahoo.com|publisher=Celtic Pro Wrestling|date=April 1, 2005|accessdate=2016-04-10}}http://www.wrestling101.com/101/newsitem/1644/ https://archive.is/ksKVL ===Other work in wrestling=== Ross and his brother Bruce started the [[Stampede Wrestling Hall of Fame]] together. In July 4, 1989 Hart was involved in an automobile accident near Jasper, Alberta together with [[Davey Boy Smith]], [[Chris Benoit]], [[Jason the Terrible|Karl Moffat]] and [[Koki Kitahara|Tatsumi Kitahara]]. Hart who was in the driver's seat and wearing a seatbelt received minor injuries, Smith who was sitting next to him and not wearing a seabelt had his head smashed through the windsheld resulting in a wound which required one hundred stitches. Karl Moffat was injured the most, one of his ankles was crushed by the spare tire. After the incident Moffat attempted to sue Hart, claiming he had been crippled by the event, but he did not succeed in receiving any compensation since a moving company Moffat had worked for supplied evidence of him moving around reasonably well after the accident.{{cite book|page=39|first=Dave|last=Meltzer|title=Tributes II: Remembering More of the World's Greatest Professional Wrestlers|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|year=2004|isbn=1-58261-817-8}}{{cite book|title=Titan Shattered: Wrestling with Confidence and Paranoia|last=Dixon|first=James|pages=105–106 pp|year=2015|publisher=History of Wrestling|ASIN=B0117TSB2G|isbn=1326355813}} Hart appeared at the [[Cauliflower Alley Club]] reunion in Las Vegas in February 2001.{{cite web|url= http://slam.canoe.com/SlamWrestlingCAC/01gallery1.html |title=Ross Hart, with Stampede Wrestling's Dick Butkus Jr. (James Trimble) at the Cauliflower Alley Club reunion in Las Vegas in February 2001|author=Greg Oliver|work=Slam! Wrestling|publisher=[[Canoe.ca|Canadian Online Explorer]]|accessdate=2016-04-02}} Since the passing of Hart family patriarch and matriarch Stu and Helen Hart, the traditional Sunday dinner is held at Ross' home.{{cite web | work = smith.hart.5 | title = The Official Page of Smith Hart| quote = Happy Easter to all my children, family, friends & fans. My sisters Georgia & Allison & my lovely niece Jennifer deserve major credit for the mighty feast. Also Happy Passover to Rabbi Gaffe and his lovely bride.|url=https://www.facebook.com/smith.hart.5/posts/277536355662912 | publisher =[[Facebook]]|date=8 April 2012| author =Hart, Smith|accessdate=2017-12-19}} Hart has long been candid about the scripted nature of professional wrestling and approved of the Calgarian civic committee's decision to exclude it from its combative sports bylaw in 2006.{{cite web |url=https://www.pressreader.com/canada/calgary-herald/20061214/282883726232859 |title=Hart gives up wrestling secret |author= Guttormson, Kim|work=|publisher=[[Calgary Herald]]|date=December 16, 2006 |accessdate=2017-12-19|via= [[PressReader]]}} In 2008 Ross Hart encouraged the city of Calgary to renovate but preserve his childhood home in its original form,{{cite web |url=https://www.pressreader.com/canada/calgary-herald/20080719/281925948785705 |title=City moves to protect more of its history |author=Leung, Terence |work=|publisher=[[Calgary Herald]]|date= July 19, 2008|accessdate=2017-12-19|via= [[PressReader]]}} this was eventually done between 2010 and 2012. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox sportsperson | name = Sally Ninham | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | headercolor = silver | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | fullname = | nickname = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | monuments = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | agent = | height = | weight = | spouse = | life_partner = | other_interests = | website = | country = Australia | sport = Rowing | disability = | disability_class = | rank = | event = | collegeteam = | universityteam = | league = | league_type = | club = [[Australian National University|ANU]] Boat Club
Melbourne University Boat Club | team = | turnedpro = | partner = | former_partner = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | worlds = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | paralympics = | highestranking = | pb = | show-medals = yes | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport | Women's [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]]}} {{MedalCountry | {{AUS}} }} {{MedalCompetition | [[World Rowing Championships]] }} {{MedalSilver| [[1990 World Rowing Championships|1990 Lake Barrington]] | [[Coxless four|LW4-]]}} }} '''Sally Ninham''' is an Australian academic, published historian and a former national representative rower. As a lightweight rower she was a national champion and won a silver medal at the [[1990 World Rowing Championships]]. ==Rowing pedigree== Ninham's uncle [[Roger Ninham]], was a dual Olympian rower for Australia. He competed at [[1960 Summer Olympics|Rome 1960]] and [[1964 Summer Olympics|Tokyo 1964]]. [http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/olympic-games/1964-Tokyo.php 1964 Olympics] He'd won the King's Cup for West Australia in 1960 and the President's Cup (national single sculls championship) in 1961. Her grandfather William Ninham a boat builder, stroked South Australian eights which contested the King's Cup in 1932, 1933 and 1935.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/interstate-championships/1933.php#M8 1933 Kings Cup] As a Perth-based craftsman of rowing shells he had long associations with the West Australian Rowing Club and the Fremantle Rowing Club.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/club-histories/fremantle/11-1.php Bill Ninham Fremantle] ==Club and state rowing== Sally Ninham's senior club rowing was from the Australian National University Boat Club and the Melbourne University Boat Club. She won a New South Wales state championship title in 1989 in a lightweight coxless four. She contested national titles at the [[Australian Rowing Championships]] in the lightweight pair and the lightweight coxless four on a number of occasions. In 1989 in ANU colours she placed second in the pair and in the four.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/national-championships/1989.php#wl2 1989 Austn C'ships] In 1990, racing for MUBC she placed fifth in the pair and fourth in the four.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/national-championships/1990-2.php#wl2 1990 Austn C'ships] Ninham's sole state representation for Victoria came in 1990 when she was selected in the bow seat of the lightweight coxless four which contested and won the Victoria Cup at the Interstate Regatta within the [[Australian Rowing Championships]]. [http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/interstate-championships/1990.php#WL4 1990 Interstate Regatta] ==International representative rowing== Ninham made her Australian representative debut in 1989 in the lightweight coxless four. They raced at the Lucerne International Regatta to a fourth place and then at the [[1989 World Rowing Championships]] in Bled they again finished fourth.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/world-championships/1989-Bled.html 1989 World C'ships]. The following year at the [[1990 World Rowing Championships]] in Lake Barrington, Ninham held the two seat in the women's lightweight four which won the silver medal.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/world-championships/1990-LakeBarrington.html 1990 World C'ships] That same crew also raced that year at the 1990 Canadian Henley Regatta and won the lightweight coxless four title. ==Scholar, author and personal== An independent scholar and author affiliated with Melbourne's La Trobe University, Ninham studied at the [[Australian National University]] and [[La Trobe University]], in Germany at the [[University of Hamburg]] and she undertook some studies at the [[University of California Berkeley]]. She obtained a BA (Hons) and a PhD.[https://sallyninham.com/about/ About Ninham] Her first published work was “A Cohort of Pioneers” a study on Australia's growing intellectual, social, and research cultures since WWII. Her second book “Ten African Cardinals” tracked conversations with ten of the fourteen African Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church.[https://sallyninham.com/books/ Ninham works] Ninham is married to James Peters, himself a national Australian champion lightweight rower (1981 coxless four) [http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/national-championships/1981.html#mlcoxed4 1981 Austn C'ships] who also coached at the Australian national level.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/world-championships/1990-LakeBarrington.html 1990 World C'ships] They have five children.[http://www.rowinghistory-aus.info/rowing-associations/victoria/appendix9-15.php#Ninham Ninham profile at Guerin Foster] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} * {{FISA|7950|Sally Ninham}} {{DEFAULTSORT: Ninham, Sally}} [[Category:Australian female rowers]] [[Category:World Rowing Championships medalists for Australia]] [[Category:Australian academics]] [[Category:Women historians]] [[Category:Australian women historians]]
