{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Sergiu Dan | image = Sergiu Dan, poet - romancier.JPG | imagesize = 220px | caption = Sergiu Dan, in a photograph taken before 1935 | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1903|12|29|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Piatra Neamț]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1976|3|13|1903|12|29|mf=y}} | death_place = | occupation = novelist, short story writer, journalist, poet, playwright, translator | nationality = Romanian | period = ca. 1925–1970 | genre = [[biographical novel]], [[collaborative fiction]], [[comedy]], [[experimental literature]], [[genre fiction]], [[historical novel]], [[political novel]], [[psychological novel]], [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]], [[Non-fiction novel|documentary novel]], [[novella]], [[parody]], [[free verse]] | movement = [[Modernist literature|Modernism]], [[Avant-garde]], [[Futurism]], ''[[Contimporanul]]'', ''[[Sburătorul]]'', [[Socialist realism]] | influences = [[Gustave Flaubert]], [[Filippo Tommaso Marinetti]], [[Pierre Alexis Ponson du Terrail]], [[Urmuz]] | influenced = | birth_name = Isidor Rotman }} '''Sergiu Dan''' ({{IPA-ro|ˈserd͡ʒju dan}}; born '''Isidor Rotman''' or '''Rottman'''; December 29, 1903 – March 13, 1976) was a Romanian novelist, journalist, [[Holocaust]] survivor and [[political prisoner]] of the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]]. Dan, the friend and collaborator of [[Romulus Dianu]], was noted during the [[interwar period]] as a contributor to Romania's [[avant-garde]] and [[Modernist literature|modernist]] scene, collaborating with poet [[Ion Vinea]] on ''[[Contimporanul]]'' review and ''[[Facla]]'' newspaper. He was also affiliated with the rival literary club, ''[[Sburătorul]]'', and noted for criticizing the [[Communism|communist]] sympathies of other avant-garde writers. His main works of the 1930s include contributions to the [[psychological novel]], [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] and [[political novel]] genres, received with critical acclaim.
Of [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish Romanian]] origin, Sergiu Dan was the subject of [[Antisemitism|antisemitic]] defamation, and, during [[World War II]], was deported to [[Transnistria (World War II)|Transnistria]]. After his return home, Dan spoke about his experiences in the book ''Unde începe noaptea'' ("Where Night Begins"), which endures one of the few Romanian contributions to [[Holocaust literature]], and has for long been censored by dictatorial regimes. The writer's political stance also clashed with the post-1948 communist establishment, and, during the 1950s, he was interned at [[Aiud prison]]. Dan was eventually forced to adapt his writing style to the aesthetic requirements of [[Socialist realism in Romania|Romanian Socialist realism]], and spent the final decades of his life in relative obscurity. His work was rediscovered and reassessed following the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|1989 Revolution]].
==Biography==
===Early decades=== The future writer was born in the town of [[Piatra Neamț]], in [[Moldavia]] region, the son of Simon Rotman.<ref name="tgjironist">{{ro icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070930080126/http://www.timpulgj.ro/arhiva/355/cultura.htm "Sergiu Dan - 'un ironist sentimental' "], in ''Timpul de Gorj'', Nr. 51 (355), December 22–28, 2008</ref> His first steps in cultural journalism happened before 1926, when he was affiliated with the newspaper ''[[Cugetul Românesc]]''; his earliest poems were published in cultural magazines such as ''[[Chemarea]]'' and ''[[Flacăra]]'',<ref name="tgjironist"/><ref name="bmlaudabil">{{ro icon}} Boris Marian, [http://www.romanianjewish.org/db/pdf/nr262_263/pagina19.pdf "Lăudabil demers: reeditarea unui roman al lui Sergiu Dan"], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Nr. 262-263 (1062-1063), December 2006, p.19</ref> and a debut [[novella]], ''Iudita și Holofern'' ("[[Judith]] and [[Holofernes]]"), saw print in 1927.<ref name="mosteniri">{{ro icon}} [http://www.romanianjewish.org/ro/mosteniri_ale_culturii_iudaice_03_11_08.html# ''Moșteniri ale culturii iudaice. Carte de neuitare a evreilor pietreni''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727222904/http://www.romanianjewish.org/ro/mosteniri_ale_culturii_iudaice_03_11_08.html |date=2011-07-27 }}, at the [http://www.romanianjewish.org/ Romanian Jewish Community site]; retrieved February 11, 2011</ref> Sergiu Dan's brother, Mihail Dan, was also a journalist, known for his translations from [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] author [[Vladimir Mayakovsky]].<ref name="pcsubterana">{{ro icon}} [[Paul Cernat]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Subterana-politica-a-avangardei-romanesti*articleID_19500-articles_details.html "Subterana politică a avangardei românești"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 417, April 2008</ref>
In the late 1920s, Sergiu Dan and his friend Romulus Dianu were in [[Bucharest]]. It was there that Dan joined the literary circle of novelist [[Camil Petrescu]], and took part in the regular literary disputes at [[Casa Capșa]] and Corso restaurants.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Geo Șerban]], [http://www.romanianjewish.org/db/pdf/nr228/pagina6-7.pdf "''D. G. L. R.'' - siglă de patrimoniu (III). Solidari cu destinele literaturii române"], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Nr. 228 (1028), April 2005, p.6-7</ref> By 1928, he had fallen out with Petrescu: ridiculing the "[[Noocracy|noocratic]]" philosophical project outlined by Petrescu, and calling its author "insane" and "poltroonish".<ref name="aiacamil">{{ro icon}} Anton I. Adămuț, [http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/images/articole/eseu%20id%20camil%20petrescu.pdf "Camil Petrescu – istoria unui manuscris (Câte ceva despre eros și despre existențialism)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928063509/http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/images/articole/eseu%20id%20camil%20petrescu.pdf |date=2011-09-28 }}, in ''[[Idei în Dialog]]'', October 2007 (republished by the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/ România Culturală] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902021335/http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/ |date=2011-09-02 }}'')</ref> He later expressed regret for the incident, noting that he had been especially amused by Petrescu's eccentric decision to store his philosophical manuscript in the [[Vatican Library]].<ref name="aiacamil"/>
Dan and Dianu were also co-opted by [[Ion Vinea]] on his various journalistic ventures, beginning with the [[left-wing]] and modernist literary review ''[[Contimporanul]]'', where they published avant-garde prose and poetry with a political subtext.<ref>Cernat, p.151, 194-197, 269</ref> His texts were featured in various other venues: ''[[Vremea]]'', ''[[Revista Fundațiilor Regale]]'', ''Universul Literar'' (the literary supplement of ''[[Universul]]'' daily) and ''[[Bilete de Papagal]]'' (the satirical newspaper of poet [[Tudor Arghezi]]).<ref name="tgjironist"/><ref name="mosteniri"/> During the period, Dan underwent formal training in [[Economics]], graduating from the [[Nicolae Kretzulescu Superior Commercial School|Bucharest Commercial School]].<ref name="tgjironist"/> With Dianu (who was also making his debut), Dan co-authored a [[Biographical novel|romanticized biography]] of the 19th century poet-storyteller [[Anton Pann]]: ''Viața minunată a lui Anton Pann'' ("The Wonderful Life of Anton Pann"; [[Editura Cultura Națională]], 1929)—this [[collaborative fiction]] piece was reissued in 1935 as ''Nastratin și timpul său'' ("[[Nasreddin]] and His Time").<ref name="gc1021; oc605">Călinescu, p.1021; Crohmălniceanu, p.353, 605, 606</ref> In this context, Dan also joined the ''[[Sburătorul]]'' club, formed around the eponymous magazine of literary theorist [[Eugen Lovinescu]], as one of the Jewish writers whom Lovinescu welcomed into his movement.<ref name="vbcuvant">{{ro icon}} [[Vlaicu Bârna]], [http://www.romlit.ro/un_cuvnt_nou_n_limba_romn "Un cuvânt nou în limba română"], in ''[[România Literarǎ]]'', Nr. 42/2001</ref><ref name="hzapropieri">{{ro icon}} [[Henri Zalis]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/ZALISaug4.html "Apropieri de o moștenire diferențiată"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', August 2004</ref>
During his period at ''Contimporanul'', Dan embarked on a conflict with the [[Surrealism|Surrealist]] and [[far left]]ist group at ''[[unu]]'', the magazine of poet [[Sașa Pană]]. This controversy reflected the major discrepancies between ''Contimporanul'' and other avant-garde venues.<ref name="pcsubterana"/> By 1930, Sergiu's brother Mihail Dan had left ''Bilete de Papagal'' and had become involved with ''unu'', of which he was later editor in chief. However, documents first made public in 2008 show that he was secretly an [[informant]] for the [[Kingdom of Romania]]'s intelligence agency, ''[[Siguranța Statului]]'', with a mission to supervise ''unu''{{'}}s ongoing flirtations with [[communism]].<ref name="pcsubterana"/> He had for long been suspected of this by the literary society at ''Sburătorul''.<ref name="vbcuvant"/> Also in 1930, shortly after the forceful return of [[King of Romania|Romanian King]] [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] to the throne, Sergiu Dan was working, as political editor,<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> on the staff of ''[[Dreptatea]]'', the platform of the [[National Peasants' Party]] (PNȚ). According to the later account of communist journalist [[Petre Pandrea]], Dan and Vinea together stole the original draft of an article by PNȚ economist [[Virgil Madgearu]], and forged it in such manner as to make it seem that Madgearu was an anti-Carlist; they then sold a copy to Madgearu's rival, the [[Corporatism|corporatist]] theorist [[Mihail Manoilescu]]. Manoilescu took a copy of this document to Carol, discrediting himself when the forgery was exposed.<ref name="pp27">[[Petre Pandrea]], "Carol II-Madgearu-Manoilescu", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', April 2002, p.27</ref> Pandrea claimed that, between them, Dan and Vinea made off with 150,000 [[Romanian leu|lei]] from the affair, whereas their victim Manoilescu fell into permanent disfavor.<ref name="pp27"/>
Sergiu Dan's actual editorial debut came in 1931, when [[Editura Cugetarea]] published his novel ''Dragoste și moarte în provincie'' ("Love and Death in the Provinces").<ref name="gc1021; oc605"/> In 1932, Dan and dramatist [[George Mihail Zamfirescu]] shared the annual prize of the [[Romanian Writers' Society]], of which they both became members.<ref name="vdssr">{{ro icon}} Victor Durnea, [http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/articol.php?cod=9830 "Societatea scriitorilor români"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218133843/http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/articol.php?cod=9830 |date=2012-02-18 }}, in ''[[Dacia Literară]]'', Nr. 2/2008 (republished by the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/ România Culturală] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902021335/http://www.romaniaculturala.ro/ |date=2011-09-02 }}'')</ref> In 1932, Sergiu Dan joined the staff of Vinea's gazette ''[[Facla]]'', with novelist [[Ion Călugăru]], poet [[N. Davidescu]], writer-director [[Sandu Eliad]], and professional journalists [[Nicolae Carandino]] and [[Henric Streitman]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Geo Șerban]], [http://www.romlit.ro/causeries_du_lundi "''Causeries du lundi''"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 25/2000</ref>
Dan resumed his writing career with ''Arsenic'', published by Cultura Națională in 1934, and ''Surorile Veniamin'' ("The Veniamin Sisters", Editura Vatra, 1935).<ref name="gc1021; oc605"/> The former volume received another cultural prize, granted by literary critics at the [[Eforie]] festival of 1934.<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> During 1934, Dan was one of 46 intellectuals who signed an appeal in favor of normalizing relations between Romania and its communist enemy to the east, the [[Soviet Union]]—the basis for a cultural and political association, ''[[Amicii URSS]]'', which was secretly maneuvered by the outlawed [[Romanian Communist Party]].<ref>[[Adrian Cioroianu]], ''{{lang|ro|Pe umerii lui Marx. O introducere în istoria comunismului românesc}}'', [[Editura Curtea Veche]], Bucharest, 2005, p.114-118. {{ISBN|973-669-175-6}}</ref>
===Between Transnistria and Aiud=== Sergiu Dan became a victim of [[antisemitism|antisemitic]] repression during the early stages of [[World War II]], when [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] and [[Fascism|fascist]] regimes took over (''see [[Romania during World War II]]''). Initially, he was expelled from the Writers' Society.<ref name="rcura">{{ro icon}} [[Radu Cosașu]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/la-centru-si-la-margine/articol/ura-in-toata-incultura-ei "Ura în toată incultura ei"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 118, April 2006</ref> In July 1940, writing for ''Universul Literar'', fascist author Ladmiss Andreescu proposed a boycott of Dan's work, and an overall ban on Jewish literature.<ref>{{ro icon}} Ladmiss Andreescu, [http://dspace.bcucluj.ro/jspui/bitstream/123456789/19002/1/BCUCLUJ_FP_P3441_1940_049_0029.pdf "Iudeii în literatura noastră"], in ''[[Universul|Universul Literar]]'', Nr. 29/1940, p.2 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> Under the [[National Legionary State]], some authors sympathetic to the ruling [[Iron Guard]] celebrated its enforcement of censorship as a revolution against modernist literature. In their magazine ''[[Gândirea]]'', Dan was referred to as an exponent of "Judaic morbidity".<ref>{{ro icon}} S[eptimiu] B[ucur], [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/gandirea/1940/BCUCLUJ_FP_279479_1940_019_007.pdf "Cronica măruntă. ''Revista Fundațiilor Regale''"], in ''[[Gândirea]]'', Nr. 7/1940, p.519 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> Dan escaped the [[Legionnaires' rebellion and Bucharest pogrom|Pogrom of January 1941]], hidden and protected by his friend Vinea.<ref>{{ro icon}} Marin Pop, [[Corneliu Coposu]], [http://www.caietesilvane.ro/indexcs.php?cmd=articol&idart=2342 "Corneliu Coposu despre atitudinea lui Iuliu Maniu față de evrei"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705081408/http://www.caietesilvane.ro/indexcs.php?cmd=articol&idart=2342 |date=2015-07-05 }}, in ''Caiete Silvane'', May 2014</ref>
Later, the new dictatorial government of ''[[Conducător]]'' [[Ion Antonescu]] listed Dan as one of the Jewish authors specifically banned, on a special inventory with nationwide circulation.<ref>Rotman, p.174-175</ref> Dan was also among the Jewish men and women who were deported to [[concentration camp]]s in Romanian-administered [[Transnistria (World War II)|Transnistria]] (''see [[Holocaust in Romania]]''); he was eventually released and could return to Bucharest, where he was under treatment with the Jewish physician and fellow writer [[Emil Dorian]], before the [[King Michael's Coup|August 1944 Coup]] managed to topple Antonescu.<ref name="lr176">Rotman, p.176</ref>
Dealing with his Transnistrian deportation, the novel ''Unde începe noaptea'' was published by Editura Naționala Mecu in 1945.<ref name="oc605">Crohmălniceanu, p.605</ref> The book, written as a response to early signs of [[Holocaust denial]],<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> was reportedly taken out of circulation for unknown reasons; it was later suggested that it clashed with the Communist Party agenda, at a time when Romania was undergoing fast [[communization]].<ref name="rehasefer">{{ro icon}} [http://www.romanianjewish.org/db/pdf/nr256_257/pagina4-5.pdf "Hasefer — ca de obicei, la înălțimea așteptărilor"], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Nr. 256-257 (1056-1057), June–July 2006, p.5</ref> Two years later, Naționala Mecu released another one of Dan's war-themed novels, ''Roza și ceilalți'' ("Roza and the Others").<ref>Călinescu, p.1021</ref>
After 1948, Sergiu Dan's political views collided with the agenda set by the [[Communist Romania|Romanian communist regime]], and he was eventually arrested. Reportedly, Dan had first attracted political persecution upon himself when, in 1947, he spoke out as a defense witness at the trial of his friend, the PNȚ journalist Nicolae Carandino.<ref name="idbalanta">{{ro icon}} Iulia Deleanu, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Epoca-interbelica-refolosirea-balantei*articleID_19031-articles_details.html "Epoca interbelică – refolosirea balanței"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 406, January 2008</ref> The [[Securitate]] secret police confiscated his works in progress, which reputedly formed part of a special secret archive.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Alex. Ștefănescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/din_realizrile_regimului_comunist_-_cri_interzise "Din 'realizările' regimului comunist - Cărți interzise"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804110725/http://www.romlit.ro/din_realizrile_regimului_comunist_-_cri_interzise |date=2012-08-04 }}, in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 50/2004</ref> The conditions of Dan's new detainment were characterized by literary historian [[Henri Zalis]] as "savage".<ref name="hzapropieri"/> He was notably held, with many other public figures of various backgrounds, at [[Aiud prison]]. Petre Pandrea, himself imprisoned there after an inner-party purge, later included Dan on his list of writers, humorously titled the "Writers' Union of Aiud"—in contrast to the communist-controlled [[Writers' Union of Romania]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Alex. Ștefănescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/petre_pandrea2 "Petre Pandrea" (II)], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 19/2003; [http://www.romlit.ro/scriitori_arestai_1944-1964 "Scriitori arestați (1944-1964)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804110804/http://www.romlit.ro/scriitori_arestai_1944-1964 |date=2012-08-04 }}, in ''România Literară'', Nr. 23/2005</ref> Dianu, who had worked with Vinea and controversial journalist [[Pamfil Șeicaru]] during the war years, was also in custody by 1950, as one of the journalists charged with having tarnished "the world's luminous transformation on the path toward the justest regime in the history of mankind".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Emil Manu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/romulus_dianu_-_versuri_inedite "Romulus Dianu - Versuri inedite"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 50/2001</ref>
Dan was eventually released around 1955, when, according to Zalis (a personal witness to the events, alongside novelist [[Zaharia Stancu]]), he confided to fellow members of the official Writers' Union about his time in prison.<ref name="hzapropieri"/> The Union later exposed Dan to sessions of "self-criticism", forcing him to comply with the demands of [[Socialist realism]] (''see [[Socialist realism in Romania]]'').<ref name="hzapropieri"/> His later bibliography includes: ''Taina stolnicesei'' ("The [[Stolnik]] Woman's Secret"), published by [[Editura de stat pentru literatură și artă]] (ESPLA) in 1958 and ''Tase cel Mare'' ("Tase the Great"), [[Editura pentru literatură]], 1964.<ref name="oc605"/>
In 1970, [[Editura Minerva]] republished ''Roza și ceilalți'' and ''Arsenic'', while [[Cartea Românească]] printed his last volume, ''Dintr-un jurnal de noapte'' ("From a Nightly Diary").<ref name="oc605"/> That year, in protest against [[Censorship in Communist Romania|communist censorship]], Dan refused to accept the ''[[Meritul Cultural]]'' medal.<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> He also concentrated on his translator's activity, being noted for his rendition of ''[[Madame Bovary]]'' and ''[[Salammbô]]'', the classical works of French novelist [[Gustave Flaubert]].<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> His overall contribution also covers [[Romanian-language]] versions of works by [[Louis Aragon]], [[Michel Droit]], [[Maurice Druon]], [[Anatole France]], [[Boris Polevoy]], [[Elsa Triolet]] and [[Voltaire]].<ref name="tgjironist"/> In 1973, he was interviewed by the young literary critics Ileana Corbea and Nicolae Florescu for the volume ''Biografii posibile'' ("Possible Biographies").<ref name="aiacamil"/>
==Work==
===Early contributions=== The earliest literary contributions by Sergiu Dan are generally small-scale narratives about provincial life, which often lead to a fiery and unexpected [[Climax (narrative)|climax]].<ref name="tgjironist"/> Those fragments published by ''[[Contimporanul]]'' in the 1920s have been included by researcher [[Paul Cernat]] in a special group of "iconoclastic" and [[Absurdism|absurdist]] short prose (with those of Dianu, [[F. Brunea-Fox]], [[Filip Corsa]] or [[Sandu Tudor]]).<ref>Cernat, p.194</ref> His [[Experimental literature|experimental prose]] fragment ''Rocambole'' was a [[parody]] of [[Pierre Alexis Ponson du Terrail]]'s [[Rocambole (character)|19th century series]] (and of literary conventions in general): although only covering half a page, it carried the subtitle "grand [[adventure novel]]", and showed its eponymous [[anti-hero]] as an [[incest]]uous [[kleptomania]]c.<ref>Cernat, p.195</ref> The inspiration behind this format, similar to those employed by Dianu and the others, was the avant-garde hero [[Urmuz]]. According to Cernat, the ''Contimporanul'' writers borrowed Urmuz's manner of toying with the expectations of traditional readers, but were less interested than him in preserving an implicit social message.<ref>Cernat, p.195-197</ref> Cernat illustrates this conclusion with Dan's [[free verse]] "diary-poem", published in Issue 71 of ''Contimporanul'', a sample of "cynical [[libertinism]]" and "absolute aesthetic freedom": {{Verse translation| mai plăcut: moartea pentru rochie decât pentru steag<ref>Cernat, p.197</ref> | more pleasant: a death for the skirt than for the flag}}
A triple issue of ''Contimporanul'' (96-97-98 for 1931) featured Dan and Dianu's text for the stage, ''Comedie în patru acte'' ("A Comedy in Four Acts"). Cernat finds that it is a "timid" version of [[Futurism|Futurist]] writings by [[Filippo Tommaso Marinetti]], comparable to similar contributions by [[A. L. Zissu]].<ref>Cernat, p.269</ref>
Dan's style became more personal during his affiliation with ''[[Sburătorul]]'' and his earliest novels, although, Henri Zalis notes, he was more eclectic than other ''Sburătorists''.<ref name="idbalanta"/> Researcher and critic [[Ovid Crohmălniceanu]] finds that Sergiu Dan was one of the [[psychological novel]]ists who, following ''Sburătorul''{{'}}s critique of [[social determinism]] and praise of the liberated urban intellectual, focused primarily (and, in Crohmălniceanu's opinion, excessively) on the refined "erotic obsessions" of exceptional individuals. He therefore places Dan in a group of ''Sburătorists'' which also includes [[Felix Aderca]], [[Isaia Răcăciuni]], [[Mihail Celarianu]] and [[Dan Petrașincu]].<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.45</ref> In his 1941 synthesis of [[Literature of Romania|Romanian literature]], academic [[George Călinescu]] described the post-1931 novels written separately by Dianu and Dan as rather similar, with the exception that Dan's were the products of "a more organized industry"; both authors, he argues, remained "highly conventional" in applying to Romania the [[genre fiction]] equivalent of [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood films]].<ref name="gc797">Călinescu, p.797</ref>
Overall, Crohmălniceanu notes, Sergiu Dan had an "offhand narrative style, moving around with ease, the same as [fellow novelist] [[Cezar Petrescu]], in quite varied environments. A certain analytical lucidity [of his] betrays [...] an additional interest for the mystery of psychological mechanisms within his heroes' actions".<ref name="oc353">Crohmălniceanu, p.353</ref> The shock value of avant-garde and libertinism is preserved in some of Dan's 1930s novels. Călinescu wrote that his characters generally lack "even the slightest notion of virtue", their "flimsy mentality" being the reason why Dan's novels always resemble "comedies".<ref name="gc797"/> However, according to Crohmălniceanu, Dan's "sharp intelligence", "delicate observation" and love of [[aphorism]] compensated for "the lack of any prolonged moral discretion."<ref name="oc353"/>
While the [[Anton Pann]] narrative earned appreciation for freely mixing [[picturesque]] elements into a [[historical novel]] framework, Dan's solo debut with ''Dragoste și moarte...'' takes direct inspiration from [[Gustave Flaubert]].<ref name="tgjironist"/> The book is seen by Ovid Crohmălniceanu as "a good reconstruction of a particular human ambiance, with a suggestion regarding the forms of [[Bovarysme]] that envelop [the provincial] setting."<ref name="oc353"/> The more complex ''Arsenic'' can be read, according to Crohmălniceanu, as both a [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] populated with "dubious" figures and, "under careful reading", a study "on the petty cowardice of existence."<ref name="oc353"/> The protagonist is a physician who renounces his professional standard, assists his friend, the simple giant Bibi, in plotting the murder of a common enemy, and then lives to regret his deed, while, at the same time, he betrays Bibi's confidence by pursuing an affair with his wife Ana; Ana however cheats on both men with the president of an insurance company.<ref>Călinescu, p.797; Crohmălniceanu, p.353</ref> Călinescu remarks that the novel was constructed with an "intelligent" rhythm of [[suspense]] and humor, noting the "fantasy" invested in the secondary plots and characters: the colonel who dies obsessing about [[fodder]], his [[bourgeois]] daughters, or the [[coroner]] who constructs absurd theories about criminal behavior.<ref name="gc797"/> ''Arsenic'' received high praise from Crohmălniceanu: "The book is written with much confidence, it displays remarkable intellectual detachment, fine [[Voltaire|Voltairian]] irony and an ingenious, irreproachable, [[counterpoint]] construction."<ref name="oc354">Crohmălniceanu, p.354</ref>
In ''Surorile Veniamin'', Dan's [[political novel]], the narrative follows the symmetrical lives of two sisters: Felicia, who rejects social conformity and braves a life of poverty; and Maria, who works in the thriving [[Oil industry in Romania|oil industry]] and then becomes a kept woman. The plot is complicated by Felicia's affair with agitator Mihai Vasiliu, a [[Romanian Communist Party]] member who is pursued by ''[[Siguranța Statului]]'' agents, and who hides in Maria's apartment.<ref>Călinescu, p.797-798; Crohmălniceanu, p.354</ref> Călinescu rated the more "serious" book as inferior to the "flighty verve" of ''Arsenic''.<ref name="gc797"/> Crohmălniceanu believes the book displays qualities similar to ''Arsenic''{{'}}s, but notes that Vasiliu's ultimate arrest, which leaves both sisters unconsoled, leads the outcome into a "disappointingly inconsistent" solution.<ref name="oc354"/>
===''Unde începe noaptea'' and later works=== With ''Unde începe noaptea'', Sergiu Dan spoke about his own experience as a victim of [[Nazism]] and of [[Ion Antonescu]]'s regime, with additional detail on the [[Legionnaires' rebellion and Bucharest pogrom|January 1941 Pogrom]].<ref name="idbalanta"/> The book carries a [[motto]] from the [[Freethought|freethinker]] [[Léon Bloy]]: "Only Jewish tears are the heaviest. Theirs is the weight of many centuries."<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> Centered on Jewish industrialist David Bainer, the narrative progresses over the slow degeneration into [[racial antisemitism]], culminating in deportation.<ref name="bmlaudabil"/>
Crohmălniceanu noted: "In grave pitch, the author manages, against previous expectations, to write a book as yet unparalleled in our literature, about [[Nazi extermination camps]]".<ref name="oc354"/> Literary critic John Neubauer and his co-authors listed Sergiu Dan among the few [[East-Central Europe]]an authors to have been caught up in wartime "carnage" and survived (their list also includes, for Romania, political prisoner [[Tudor Arghezi]] and Holocaust survivor [[Elie Wiesel]]).<ref>Neubauer ''et al.'', p.147</ref> They describe ''Unde începe...'' as "a [[Non-fiction novel|documentary novel]] about life in the concentration camp", one of the first-generation East-Central European books to deal with the World War II tragedy. The category places Dan among [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavs]] [[Vladimir Dedijer]], [[Vladimir Nazor]] and [[Viktor Novak]]; [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovaks]] [[Ján Bodenek]], [[Jan Drda]], [[Miloš Krno]] and [[Jozef Horák]]; Polish [[Kazimierz Brandys]], [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[Ernő Szép]] and [[Bulgaria]]n [[Iordan Velchev]].<ref>Neubauer ''et al.'', p.164</ref> This view is contrasted by poet and critic Boris Marian, who finds that the narrative, which displays "impressive realism" and "alert style", is not documentary, but rather personal; according to him, although briefly showing communists at work, ''Unde începe...'' goes against its time by not presenting them in an ideal light.<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> According to Henri Zalis, Dan's account forms "an ample [[novella]]" about "the inferno of a Nazi camp".<ref name="hzapropieri"/>
In ''Roza și ceilalți'', the libertine daughter of a Jewish tailor is persuaded by her coreligionists into accepting the sexual advances of a [[Nazi Germany|Nazi German]] officer. Called a "tragic buffoonery" by George Călinescu (in an updated version of his 1941 overview), the narrative culminates with the German retreat, after which Roza, branded a [[Collaboration with the Axis Powers during World War II|collaborator]], is tortured and raped by her own community.<ref>Călinescu, p.798</ref>
Essentially an [[anti-communist]], Dan refused to comply with the requirements imposed on literature by the [[Socialist realism in Romania|Socialist realist establishment]] during the late 1940s.<ref name="hzapropieri"/> However, giving in to political pressure after his return from jail, he produced ''Tase cel Mare'': called an "accessible" and "simplistic" novel by Zalis,<ref name="hzapropieri"/> it is thematically linked to the world depicted in ''Surorile Veniamin''.<ref name="tgjironist"/>
==Legacy== Essayist and literary historian [[Barbu Cioculescu]] recalled that Dan, "an excellent writer and man of character", was vilified in the 1940s by a "wretched [[epigram]]".<ref name="bcchinez">{{ro icon}} [[Barbu Cioculescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/a_fi_chinez_lapon_hindus.. "A fi chinez, lapon, hindus..."], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 29/2003</ref> The antisemitic rhyme went as follows: {{Verse translation| După nume, Sergiu Dan N-ai zice că e jidan. După chip și-obrăznicie Nu se poate să nu fie.<ref name="bcchinez"/> | With a name like Sergiu Dan You wouldn't think he'd be a kike. With his features and his sass He couldn't be anything but.}}
During the antisemitic censoring and deportation of Sergiu Dan, George Călinescu still defied the political restrictions. His work still included literary profiles of Dan and other Jewish Romanian writers.<ref>Rotman, p.175-177. See also [[Alexandru Piru]], preface to Călinescu, p.X-XI</ref> This gesture of goodwill was acknowledged by Dan. He spoke to [[Emil Dorian]] about the Antonescu regime's attempt to circulate an alternative, antisemitic, Romanian literature tract, overseen by [[Ion Petrovici]].<ref name="lr176"/> Călinescu's defiance was perceived as an outrage by Romania's [[Fascism|fascist]] periodicals. The newspaper ''[[Porunca Vremii]]'' called for Călinescu to be punished for his attack on "the cleanliness of the Romanian soul". It asserted that Jewish writers, Dan included, had no part to play in [[Culture of Romania|Romanian culture]].<ref name="rcura"/> The same was stated in ''[[Gândirea]]''. It argued that, in reviewing Dan and the others, Călinescu had soiled the "Romanian blood that was shed under the pointy claw of the [[Talmud]]".<ref>{{ro icon}} Petru P. Ionescu, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/gandirea/1941/BCUCLUJ_FP_279479_1941_020_008.pdf "''Istoria literaturii române''"], in ''[[Gândirea]]'', Nr. 8/1941, p.442 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
After renewed [[Censorship in Communist Romania|communist censorship]], Sergiu Dan's work was again given consideration in Communist Romania during the 1960s [[liberalization]] episode. However, researcher [[Radu Ioanid]] notes, his references to the Holocaust were uncomfortable subjects for the [[National communism|national communist]] apparatus. Ioanid speaks about "selective censorship" on Romanian Holocaust literature, with Dan being one of the few authors whose works on the topic remained publishable.<ref name="ri238">[[Radu Ioanid]], "Romania", in [[David S. Wyman]], Charles H. Rosenzveig (eds.), ''The World Reacts to the Holocaust'', [[Johns Hopkins University Press]], Baltimore & London, 1996, p.238. {{ISBN|0-8018-4969-1}}</ref> Some other such exceptions are [[Camil Baltazar]], [[Maria Banuș]], [[Aurel Baranga]], [[F. Brunea-Fox]], [[Eusebiu Camilar]], [[Georgeta Horodincă]], [[Alexandru Ivasiuc]], [[Norman Manea]], [[Sașa Pană]] and [[Titus Popovici]].<ref name="ri238"/> A reprint of ''Unde începe noaptea'' was still not possible, even though Carandino, newly released from prison, pleaded on this issue with communist [[President of Romania|President]] [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]].<ref name="rehasefer"/>
After the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]], Dan remained largely unknown to the Romanian public. Boris Marian wrote in 2006: "more gifted, we believe, than any one of his better-known colleagues, [Sergiu Dan] is a name rarely mentioned nowadays."<ref name="bmlaudabil"/> Henri Zalis took special care to republish and reevaluate the early work of Sergiu Dan and other Jewish Romanians, a conscious effort to reduce the impact of antisemitic or communist repression. According to fellow critic Ovidiu Morar, this reevaluation of the political aspect was groundbreaking, and "worthy of appreciation".<ref name="ovcondensata">{{ro icon}} Ovidiu Morar, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/MORARapr6.html "''O istorie condensatǎ a literaturii române''"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', April 2006</ref> Cultural journalist Iulia Deleanu also noted that, in his treatment of Dan and other persecuted Jewish writers of that generation, Zalis acted as a "diagnostician".<ref name="idbalanta"/> Of Dan's contribution, Zalis noted: "[it] must not be forgotten [since] it speaks of an experienced tragedy, one that is inseparable from the history of [his] century. A history that belongs to us, once it is no longer overlooked."<ref name="ovcondensata"/> During [[Bookfest]] 2006, Zalis and [[Editura Hasefer]], the Jewish Romanian publishing house, released a critical edition of ''Unde începe noaptea''.<ref name="rehasefer"/><ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.cronicaromana.ro/index.php?editie=1073&art=53404 "Știri. Lansări de carte la Târgul de Carte Bookfest"], in ''[[Cronica Română]]'', June 16, 2006</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== *[[George Călinescu]], ''Istoria literaturii române de la origini pînă în prezent'', [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1986 *[[Paul Cernat]], ''Avangarda românească și complexul periferiei: primul val'', [[Cartea Românească]], Bucharest, 2007. {{ISBN|978-973-23-1911-6}} *[[Ovid Crohmălniceanu]], ''Literatura română între cele două războaie mondiale'', Vol. I, Editura Minerva, Bucharest, 1972. {{OCLC|490001217}} *John Neubauer ''et al.'', "1945", in [[Marcel Cornis-Pope]], John Neubauer (eds.), ''History of the Literary Cultures of East-Central Europe: Junctures and Disjunctures in the 19th and 20th Centuries'', [[John Benjamins]], Amsterdam & Philadelphia, 2004, p. 143-176. {{ISBN|90-272-3452-3}} *{{ro icon}} Liviu Rotman (ed.), ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20110818231335/http://jewishfed.ro/fcer/public_html/downloads/carti/Demnitate.pdf Demnitate în vremuri de restriște]'', [[Editura Hasefer]], [[Federation of Jewish Communities of Romania]] & [[Elie Wiesel National Institute for Studying the Holocaust in Romania]], Bucharest, 2008. {{ISBN|978-973-630-189-6}} {{Authority control}}

'''Suliman Bashear''' [[PhD]] ({{lang-ar|<big>سليمان بشير</big>}}, Sulaymān Bashīr, {{lang-he|סולימאן בשיר}}; 1947–October 1991) was a leading Druze Arab scholar and professor, who taught at [[Birzeit University]], [[An-Najah National University]], and the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. Bashear was noted for his work on the early historiography of Islam.
== Life and education==
Bashear was born in the northern [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian]] village of [[Mghar]]. Bashear studied at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] for his [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] (1971) and [[Master of Arts|MA]] (1973). In 1976, he received his [[PhD]] at the [[University of London]] for his dissertation ‘Communism in the Arab East’, which was published both in [[Arabic]] and in [[English language|English]].
He died in October 1991 following a heart attack, cutting short a promising career. In the last six years of his life, he had produced no less than fifteen published articles.<ref>Obituary in introduction to Studies in early Islamic tradition by Laurence Conrad, University of Hamburg</ref>
==Thesis== Bashear made international headlines when he was injured after allegedly being thrown from a second-story window by his students at the University of Nablus in the West Bank as he argued that [[Islam]] developed as a religion gradually within the historical context of [[Judaism]] and [[Christianity]] rather than being the revelation of a [[prophet]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/02/arts/scholars-are-quietly-offering-new-theories-of-the-koran.html The New York Times Radical New Views of Islam and the Origins of the Koran]</ref> However, this incident has been denied by Bashear’s wife, Dr. Lily Feidy, where she wrote in an email message, “Please note that Suliman was never attacked or injured by his students; nor was he physically attacked by anybody else. I have been asked this question a million times”.<ref>Sadeghi, Behnam, and Mohsen Goudarzi. "Ṣan ‘ā’1 and the Origins of the Qur’ān." Der Islam 87.1-2 (2012), page 32. DOI: [https://dx.doi.org/10.1515/islam-2011-0025 10.1515/islam-2011-0025]</ref>
Bashear's historiography of early Islam considered not only the development of religious customs and beliefs, but also traced how later generations recast the past in order to meet the needs of their own era. Like the work of [[Patricia Crone]], [[John Wansbrough]], [[Yehuda D. Nevo]], and other historiographers of early Islam, Bashear's research challenged what he considered to be the myth of a unified beginning Islam.
== Books and articles == * ''Communism in the Arab East: 1918–28''. London: [[Ithaca Press]], 1980. * ''Muqaddimah fī at-tārīkh al-ākhar: Naḥ̣ḥwa qirāʾah jadīdah l-il-riwāyah al-Islāmiyyah'' [''An Introduction to the other history: Towards a new reading of Islamic tradition'']. Jerusalem, 1984. [Arabic] * ‘[https://www.jstor.org/stable/617216 Qurʾān 2:114 and Jerusalem]’. ''[[Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies]]'' 52.2 (1989): 215-238. * ‘[https://www.jstor.org/stable/4057221 Yemen in early Islam: An Examination of non-tribal traditions]’. ''[[Arabica (journal)|Arabica]]'' 36.3 (November 1989): 327-361. * ‘Abraham’s sacrifice of his son and related issues’. ''[[Der Islam]]'' 67 (1990): 243-277. * ‘[https://www.jstor.org/stable/1595775 The Title «''fārūq''» and its association with ʿUmar I]’. ''[[Studia Islamica]]'' 72 (1990): 47-70. * ‘Apocalyptic and other materials on early Muslim-Byzantine wars: A Review of Arabic sources’. ''[[Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society]]'' 3rd s. 1.2 (1991): 173-207. * ‘[http://menadoc.bibliothek.uni-halle.de/dmg/periodical/titleinfo/150543 ʿĀshūrā, an early Muslim fast]’. ''[[Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft]]'' 141.2 (1991): 281-316. * ‘The Mission of Diḥya al-Kalbī and the situation in Syria’. ''[[Jerusalem Studies in Arabic and Islam]]'' 14 (1991): 84-114. * ‘Qibla musharriqa and early Muslim prayer in churches’. ''[[The Muslim World]]'' 81 (1991): 267-282. * ‘Riding beasts on divine missions: An Examination of the ass and camel traditions’. ''[[Journal of Semitic Studies]]'' 36.1 (Spring 1991): 37-75. * ‘The Images of Mecca: A Case study in Muslim iconography’. ''[[Le Muséon]]'' 105 (1992): 361-377. * ‘Muslim apocalypses and the Hour: A Case-study in traditional interpretation’. ''[[Israel Oriental Studies]]'' 13 (1993): 75-99. * ‘On the origin and development of zakāt in early Islam’. ''[[Arabica (journal)|Arabica]]'' 40 (1993): 84-113.<ref>Fred McGraw Donner - 2010 "The original concept of zakat or sadaqa as a payment in expiation for sin, rather than alms, is brilliantly explored in Suliman Bashear, "On the Origins and Development of the Meaning of Zakat in Islam," Arabica 40 (1993): 84-113"</ref> * ‘''[[Qunut|Qunūt]]'' in ''tafsīr'' and ''ḥadīth'' literatures’. ''[[Jerusalem Studies in Arabic and Islam]]'' 19 (1995): 36-65. * ''Arabs and others in early Islam''. Princeton: [[Darwin Press]], 1997. * ''Judhur al-wisayah al-Urduniyah: Dirasah fi wathaʾiq al-Arshif as-Sihyuni''. Beirut: Sharikat Quds, 2001. [Arabic] * ''Studies in early Islamic tradition''. Collected Studies in Arabic and Islam. Jerusalem: Max Schloessinger Memorial Foundation, [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], 2004. **''This collects thirteen published articles listed above, as well as the following two unpublished studies: ‘Ḥanīfiyya and the ''ḥajj''’ and ‘Jesus in an early Muslim ''shahāda'' and related issues: A New perspective’.
== Bibliography == * [[Devin J. Stewart|Stewart, Devin J]]. [http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=5336652 Review] of Suliman Bashear, ''Studies in early Islamic tradition'' (Jerusalem: Max Schloessinger Memorial Foundation, [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], 2004). ''[[International Journal of Middle East Studies]]'' 41.2 (May 2009): 321-322.

{{History of Lebanon}} __NOTOC__ This is a '''timeline of Lebanese history''', comprising important legal and territorial changes and political events in [[Lebanon]] and its predecessor states. To read about the background to these events, see [[History of Lebanon]]. See also the [[list of Presidents of Lebanon]] and [[list of Prime Ministers of Lebanon]]. {{Dynamic list}}
'''Millennia''': [[#2nd millennium BC|2nd BC–1st BC]]{{·}}[[#1st millennium|1st–2nd]]{{·}}[[#3rd millennium|3rd]] ----{{anchor|2nd millennium BC}} '''Centuries''': [[#14th century BC|14th BC]]{{·}}[[#13th century BC|13th BC]]{{·}}[[#12th century BC|12th BC]]{{·}}[[#11th century BC|11th BC]]{{·}}[[#10th century BC|10th BC]]{{·}}[[#9th century BC|9th BC]]{{·}}[[#8th century BC|8th BC]]{{·}}[[#7th century BC|7th BC]]{{·}}[[#6th century BC|6th BC]]{{·}}[[#5th century BC|5th BC]]{{·}}[[#4th century BC|4th BC]]{{·}}[[#3rd century BC|3rd BC]]{{·}}[[#2nd century BC|2nd BC]]{{·}}[[#1st century BC|1st BC]]{{·}}[[#See_also|See also]]{{·}}[[#Further_reading|Further reading]]
== 14th century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | [[1400s BC (decade)|1400 BC]] || || The height of the Canaanite town of [[Ugarit]]. |} == 13th century BC == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 12th century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1200s BC (decade)|1200 BC]] || || Phoenicians invent the [[Phoenician alphabet|alphabet]] and the [[Tyrian Purple]] which was a major component in their trade. |- | || A crisis led to the [[Bronze Age collapse]]. Cities all around the eastern Mediterranean were sacked within a span of a few decades by assorted raiders. |} == 11th century BC == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 10th century BC == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 9th century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | [[840s BC|842 BC]] || || [[Shalmaneser III]] devastates the territory of [[Damascus]]; [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] and the Phoenician cities send tribute. |- | [[810s BC|813 BC]] || || [[Carthage]] is founded by Phoenicians. |} == 8th century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | [[770s BC|774 BC]] || || The reign of king [[Pygmalion of Tyre|Pygmalion]] of [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]] ends. |- | [[730s BC|739 BC]] || || [[Hiram II]] becomes king of Tyre. |- | [[730s BC|730 BC]] || || [[Mattan II]] succeeds [[Hiram II]] as king. |- | [[720s BC|724 BC]] || || The [[Assyria]]ns under king [[Shalmaneser V]] start a four-year siege of Tyre that ends in 720 BC. |- | [[710s BC|710 BC]] || || [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]], Tyre and Sidon revolt against Assyria. |- | [[700s BC (decade)|701 BC]] || || The Assyrian siege of Tyre by king [[Sennacherib]]. |} == 7th century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 663 BC || || The Assyrian siege of Tyre by king [[Ashurbanipal]]. |} == 6th century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 587 BC || || The region is annexed to the Babylonian empire, while [[Jerusalem]] fell into their hands. |- | 586 BC || || The [[Babylonia]]ns under king [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] sieged Tyre for thirteen years without success. Later a compromise peace was made in which Tyre had to pay tribute to the Babylonians. (to 573 BC) |- | [[530s BC|539 BC]] || || [[Cyrus the Great]] conquered Phoenicia. |} == 5th century BC == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 4th century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 350 BC || || A rebellion in [[Sidon]] led by [[Tennes]] was crushed by [[Artaxerxes III]], and its destruction was dramatically described by [[Diodorus Siculus]]. (to 345 BC) |- | 332 BC || || [[Alexander the Great]] took Tyre following the city's [[Siege of Tyre (332 BC)|siege]]. After Alexander's death Phoenicia witnessed a succession of Hellenistic rulers: [[Laomedon]] (323 BC), [[Ptolemy I]] (320 BC), [[Antigonus II]] (315 BC), [[Demetrius]] (301 BC), and [[Seleucus I Nicator|Seleucus]] (296 BC). |- | 315 BC || || Alexander's former general Antigonus begins his own siege of Tyre, taking the city a year later. |} == 3rd century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 286 BC || || Phoenicia (except for [[Arwad|Aradus]]) fell to the [[Ptolemaic dynasty|Ptolemies]] of [[Egypt]]. |} == 2nd century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 197 BC || || Phoenicia along with Syria reverted to the [[Seleucids]], and the region became increasingly [[Hellenization|Hellenized]], although Tyre actually became autonomous in 126 BC, followed by Sidon in 111 BC. |- | 140 BC || || [[Beirut]] was taken and destroyed by [[Diodotus Tryphon]] in his contest with [[Antiochus VII Sidetes]] for the throne of the [[Seleucid]] monarchy. It was later named ''Laodicea in Phoenicia'' ({{lang-el|Λαοδικεια ή του Φοινίκη}}). |} == 1st century BC == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 82 BC || || Syria, including Phoenicia, were seized by king [[Tigranes the Great]] who was later defeated by [[Lucullus]]. (to 69 BC) |- | 65 BC || || [[Pompey]] finally incorporated Phoenicia as part of the [[Syria (Roman province)|Roman province of Syria]]. |- | 64 BC || || Beirut was conquered by [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa|Agrippa]] and the city was renamed in honour of the emperor's daughter, Julia; its full name became ''Colonia Julia Augusta Felix Berytus''. |- | 27 BC || || the [[Pax Romana]] period, inhabitants of the principal Phoenician cities of [[Byblos]], [[Sidon]], and Tyre were granted Roman citizenship, while economic and intellectual activities flourished. (to AD 180) |} {{anchor|1st millennium}}
'''Centuries''': [[#1st century|1st]]{{·}}[[#2nd century|2nd]]{{·}}[[#3rd century|3rd]]{{·}}[[#4th century|4th]]{{·}}[[#5th century|5th]]{{·}}[[#6th century|6th]]{{·}}[[#7th century|7th]]{{·}}[[#8th century|8th]]{{·}}[[#9th century|9th]]{{·}}[[#10th century|10th]]{{·}}[[#11th century|11th]]{{·}}[[#12th century|12th]]{{·}}[[#13th century|13th]]{{·}}[[#14th century|14th]]{{·}}[[#15th century|15th]]{{·}}[[#16th century|16th]]{{·}}[[#17th century|17th]]{{·}}[[#18th century|18th]]{{·}}[[#19th century|19th]]{{·}}[[#20th century|20th]]
== 1st century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 20 || || Beirut's school of law was founded, it later became widely known in the surrounding region. Two of Rome's most famous jurists, [[Papinian]] and [[Ulpian]] (both natives of Phoenicia), were taught at the law school under the [[Severan dynasty|Severan]] emperors. |- | 50 || || Saint [[Paul of Tarsus]] begins his third mission and preaches in [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]]. |} == 2nd century == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 3rd century == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 4th century == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 5th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 451 || || The [[Maronite Church|Maronites]], a Christian community named after Saint [[John Maron]] sought refuge in the mountains of Lebanon. |} == 6th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 551 || || Beirut is destroyed by an [[551 Beirut earthquake|earthquake and tsunami]]. About 30,000 were killed in the city alone and, along the Phoenician coast, total casualties were close to 250,000. |} == 7th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 630 || || The Marada, a group of autonomous [[Maronite]] communities, settled in [[Mount Lebanon]] and the surrounding highlands following the conquest of Syria by the Arab [[caliphate]]. |- | 632 || || Calling for a [[jihad]] against non-[[Muslim]]s, [[Muhammad]]'s successor, [[Caliph]] [[Abu Bakr]], brought [[Islam]] to the area surrounding Lebanon. (to 634) |- | 661 || || After the [[Battle of Yarmuk]], Caliph [[Umar]] appointed the Arab [[Muawiyah I]], founder of the Umayyad dynasty, as governor of [[Syria]], an area that included present-day Lebanon. |- | 667 || || Muawiyah negotiated an agreement with [[Constantine IV]], the Byzantine emperor, whereby he agreed to pay Constantine an annual tribute in return for the cessation of Marada incursions. |- | 670 || || [[Callinicus of Heliopolis#History|Callinicus]] of [[Baalbek|Heliopolis]], a Byzantine [[chemist]] from Heliopolis, invents the [[Greek fire]] in [[Constantinople]]. |} == 8th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 759 || || An abortive rebellion of Lebanese mountaineers against the Abbasid rule after the harsh treatment of people living in the Lebanese-Syrian region. |} == 9th century == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 10th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 960 || || Prince 'Allaqa of [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]] proclaimed his independence from the Abbasids and coined money in his own name. |- | 970 || || The Fatimides settled in [[Egypt]] and extended their authority to the coastal region of [[Bilad al-Sham]] and [[Damascus]]. |- | 986 || || Under the Fatimid Caliph [[Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah]], a new religion was born and spread by a man called [[Ad-Darazi]]. This was the beginning of the [[Druze]] religion and its expansion in several Lebanese regions. |} == 11th century == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 12th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1110 || || [[Beirut]] and [[Sidon]] are captured. |- | 1124 || || Tyre resisted the raids but finally capitulated after a long siege. |- | 1179 || || The [[Battle of Marj Ayyun]] took place on 10 June, where an Ayyubid army commanded by Saladin defeated a Crusader army led by King [[Baldwin IV of Jerusalem]]. |- | 1182 || || The [[Battle of Belvoir Castle (1182)|Battle of Belvoir Castle]] in which a Crusader force led by King Baldwin IV of Jerusalem sparred inconclusively with an Ayyubid army from Egypt commanded by Saladin. The theatre of operations included [[Eilat]], the [[Oultrejordain|Transjordan]], [[Galilee]] and [[Beirut]] (which witnessed a siege by Saladin that ended in August of the same year). |- | 1187 || || Saladin conquers virtually all of the Kingdom of Jerusalem with the exception of Tyre, which held out under [[Conrad of Montferrat]]. |- | 1192 || || [[Richard I of England|Richard the Lionheart]] signed a treaty with [[Saladin]], restoring the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]] to a coastal strip between [[Jaffa]] and [[Beirut]]. |} == 13th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1260 || || The county of Tripoli becomes a vassal state of the [[Mongol Empire]]. |- | 1289 || || The county of Tripoli [[Fall of Tripoli (1289)|falls]] into the hands of the [[Mamluk]]s after the attack of [[Egypt]]ian [[Sultan]] [[Qalawun]] in March. |- | 1291 || || The [[Shia Islam|Shia Muslims]] and [[Druze]], in Lebanon, rebelled against the Mamluks who were busy fighting the European Crusaders and Mongols. |} == 14th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1308 || || The rebellion was crushed by the Mamluks. |} == 15th century == {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} == 16th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1516 || || The Ottoman Sultan [[Selim I]] grants [[Emir]] [[Fakhr ad-Din I]] a semi-autonomous reign in Lebanon. |- | 1570 || || The Maanid period reaches its peak with the reign of [[Fakhr ad-Din II]]. (to 1635) |} == 17th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1613 || || Fakhr ad-Din II is exiled to [[Tuscany]] after his inability to defeat the army of [[Ahmad al Hafiz]], the governor of [[Damascus]]. |- | 1618 || || Fakhr ad-Din II returns to Lebanon with the beginning of [[Muhammad Pasha]]'s reign as the new governor of Damascus. |- | 1622 || || The [[Battle of Anjar]] took place on 31 October, near ''Majdal Anjar'' between the army of Fakhr ad-Din II and an Ottoman army led by the governor of Damascus Mustafa Pasha. |- | 1635 || || By the orders of [[Murad IV]], Kutshuk, the governor of Damascus, defeats Fakhr ad-Din who was later executed in [[Constantinople]]. |} == 18th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1799 || || [[Bashir Shihab II|Bashir II]] declines to assist the siege of [[Acre, Israel|Acre]] by [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon]] and [[Jezzar Pasha]]. Unable to conquer Acre, Napoleon returned to [[Egypt]], and the death of Jezzar Pasha in 1804 removed Bashir's principal opponent in the area. |} == 19th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1831 || || Bashir II breaks away from the Ottoman Empire, allies with [[Muhammad Ali of Egypt]] and assists Muhammad Ali's son, [[Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt|Ibrahim Pasha]], in another siege of Acre. This siege lasted seven months, the city falling on 27 May 1832. The Egyptian army, with assistance from Bashir's troops, also attacked and conquered Damascus on 14 June 1832. |- | 1840 || || After Muhammad Ali's rejection of the requests of the London treaty signed on 15 June 1840, Ottoman and British troops landed on the Lebanese coast on 10 September 1840. Faced with this combined force, Muhammad Ali retreated, and on 14 October 1840, Bashir II surrendered to the British and went into exile. |- | 1841 || || Conflicts between the [[Druze]] and the [[Maronite Church|Maronite]] Christians exploded. A Maronite revolt against the Feudal class erupted, and lasted until 1858. |- | 1860 || || A full-scale war erupted between Maronites and Druze. [[Napoleon III of France]] sent 7,000 troops to [[Beirut]] and helped impose a partition: The Druze control of the territory was recognised as the fact on the ground, and the Maronites were forced into an [[Enclave and exclave|enclave]], arrangements ratified by the concert of Europe in 1861. |- |- | 1890 || || The "silk crisis" took place. Cheaper and better quality Chinese silk and silk products flooded Lebanese silk's main market: Europe. The crisis was especially hard considering many had taken on large debt to expand their lands and plant mulberry trees -which leaves were used to feed the worm. |} == 20th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 1914 || || After the abolishment of Lebanon's semiautonomous status, [[Jamal Pasha]] militarily occupies Lebanon. |- | 1915 || || Jamal Pasha initiates a blockade of the entire eastern [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] coast. Lebanon witnessed thousands of deaths from widespread [[famine]] and [[Plague (disease)|plagues]]. ([[Great Famine of Mount Lebanon]]) |- | 1916 || || [[Turkey|Turkish]] authorities publicly executed 21 Syrians and Lebanese in [[Damascus]] and [[Beirut]], respectively, for alleged anti-Turkish activities.[http://countrystudies.us/lebanon/19.htm http://countrystudies.us/lebanon/19.htm], Lebanon – WORLD WAR I. Retrieved on 6 July 2008. |- | 1918 || || British general [[Edmund Allenby, 1st Viscount Allenby|Edmund Allenby]] and [[Faisal I of Iraq|Faysal I]], son of [[Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca|Sharif Hussein of Mecca]], moved into [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] with British and Arab forces, thus opening the way for the occupation of Lebanon. |- | 1920 || || France takes control over Lebanese territory after the [[San Remo conference]]. |- | 1943 ||22 November|| On 22 November, Lebanon gains its [[Lebanese Independence Day|independence]] after national and international pressure following the imprisonment of president [[Bechara El Khoury]] and other parliament members by the French. |- | 1947 ||29 November || The [[United Nations General Assembly]] recommended the adoption and implementation of the [[United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine]]. |- | 1948 || || The state of [[Israel]] was declared. [[Palestinians in Lebanon|Palestinian refugees]] begin arriving in Lebanon. |- | 1958 || || A civil war erupts but short lived after the intervention of 5,000 [[United States Marine Corps|US Marines]] ordered by President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Eisenhower]] upon the request of the Lebanese president [[Camille Chamoun]]. |- | 1975 || || The [[Lebanese Civil War]] and Israeli Invasions. (to 1990) |- | 1990 || || A period of fifteen years of [[Syrian occupation of Lebanon|Syrian occupation]] starts when Syrian troops invade the Baabda residential Palace on 13 October 1990 and overthrow then President General Michel Aoun, and ends with the peaceful [[Cedar Revolution]] of more than one million protesters in Beirut central district, following the assassination of the Lebanese [[Prime minister|PM]] [[Rafik Hariri]] and the withdrawal of the Syrian troops. (to 2005) |} {{anchor|3rd millennium}} == 21st century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width:6%" | Year || style="width:10%" | Date || Event |- | 2000 || || [[South Lebanon conflict (1985–2000)|Israeli withdrawal]] from the South of Lebanon. |- | 2006 ||July–August || The [[2006 Lebanon War|July War]] takes place between [[Hezbollah]] and [[Israel]], with Israel launching a major military attack, bombing the southern suburbs of [[Beirut]], the [[Beirut–Rafic Hariri International Airport]] and parts of southern Lebanon, in response to the capture of 2 Israeli soldiers by Hezbollah on 12 July. The conflict ends with the acceptance of the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701]] by both Israel and Lebanon. Israeli force withdraw back to the international borders. Even though the resolution calls for the disarmament of [[Hezbollah]], both the Lebanese government and [[United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon|UNIFIL]] have stated that they will not disarm Hezbollah."[[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701]]"[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14649284 "BBC News – Lebanon profile "]"[[2006 Lebanon War]]" |} ==See also== * [[Timeline of Beirut]] * [[League of Nations mandate]] == References == {{reflist}} * {{refbegin}}http://www.destinationlebanon.gov.lb, Historical Timeline. Retrieved on 2008-06-13.{{refend}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080316025549/http://www.mountlebanon.org/historyoflebanon.html History of Lebanon] * [http://timelines.ws/countries/LEBANON.HTML Detailed timeline of Lebanese history] ==Further reading== * {{Citation |publisher = Ward, Lock & Co. |publication-place = London |title = [[Haydn's Dictionary of Dates]] |author = Benjamin Vincent |edition = 25th |publication-date = 1910 |chapter=Lebanon |chapterurl= http://hdl.handle.net/2027/loc.ark:/13960/t89g6g776?urlappend=%3Bseq=832 |via=Hathi Trust }} * {{cite book|publisher=[[Europa Publications]] |title= Political Chronology of the Middle East|year= 2001|isbn=978-1-135-35673-6 |chapter=Lebanon |chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=eCSOT0_JAnwC&pg=PA159 }} * {{cite book|author=Paul Doyle|title=Lebanon|year= 2012|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1-84162-370-2 |chapter= Chronology |chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=tzsRk0hvb_MC&pg=PA10 }} * {{cite book|author=William Harris|title=Lebanon: A History, 600–2011 |year=2012 |publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-998658-3 |chapter=Timeline for Lebanon and its Communities |chapterurl= https://books.google.com/books?id=J-EvNaeh6gsC&pg=PR23 }} ==External links== * [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14649284 BBC News – Lebanon profile ] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061029150108/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/un/res181.htm The Avalon Project – United Nations General Assembly Resolution 181] {{Years in Lebanon}} [[Category:History of Lebanon| ]] [[Category:Timelines by country|Lebanese]]

{{Primary sources|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox university |name= '''Turku Centre for Medieval and Early Modern Studies''' |image_name= TUCEMEMS logo.jpg |image_size= 180px |established= 2009 |city= [[Turku]] |country= [[Finland]] {{flagicon|Finland}} |type= research institute |parent =[[University of Turku]] |chairperson= [[Marjo Kaartinen]] |campus= Urban |address = Turku, Finland |affiliations =[[University of Turku]] |affiliation = None |website = http://www.tucemems.utu.fi
}}
'''Turku Centre for Medieval and Early Modern Studies''', (abbr. '''TUCEMEMS''')is a research Centre of the [[University of Turku]]. The Centre encourages research in the fields of medieval and early modern studies. To achieve this aim, the Centre coordinates research of the different disciplines of the University. The Centre has also active international collaboration with various other centres and Universities around the world.<ref name="TUCEMEMS">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/Pages/home.aspx TUCEMEMS homepage], The official website of the Centre.</ref><ref name="Partners">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/links/Pages/home.aspx TUCEMEMS partners], The official website of the Centre.</ref>
== Activity == TUCEMEMS had over 120 members<ref name="Members">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/members/Pages/home.aspx TUCEMEMS Members], The official website of the Centre.</ref> in August 2014, from many separate departments and faculties of the University of Turku.
The Centre has active international cooperation with many universities. Many scholars from different countries have visited TUCEMEMS and given lectures or held courses on varying themes. TUCEMEMS has also organized international conferences for scholars, as the Framing Premodern desires –colloquium, organized in April 2014.<ref name="Activity ">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/news-and-events/Pages/home.aspx Activity], The official website of the Centre.</ref> The colloquium discussed the themes of sexuality and sexual control in medieval and early modern societies.<ref name="FDP">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/news-and-events/colloquiums/premoderndesires/Pages/home.aspx Framing Premodern Desires], The official homepage of the colloquium.</ref>
A very important form of activity for the Centre is the scholarly publication series, Crossing Boundaries: Turku Medieval and Early Modern Studies, published by Amsterdam University Press. TUCEMEMS has the general editorship of this scholarly series. The Centre has an Editorial Board consisting of professors and other researchers from the University of Turku, and an advisory board composed of professors and other experts from the relevant fields of study from multiple Universities from around the world.<ref name="Publications">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/publications/Pages/home.aspx Publications], The official website of the Centre.</ref>
The activities of the Centre include lectures, seminars and conferences on varying themes.<ref name="TUCEMEMS" /> The Centre organizes Monthly Talks, where researchers present their research themes to other scholars.<ref name="Activity " />
[[File:Sirkkalan kasarmi.jpg|thumb|The Sirkkala Campus in Turku, were much of the activities of TUCEMEMS takes place.]]
=== Administration ===
TUCEMEMS has a board of ten Members and ten Deputies. The Board is chaired by a Chairperson, who from the beginning of the Centre has been Professor Marjo Kaartinen from the Department of Cultural History of the University of Turku. The Members of the board consists of Professors from the University of Turku, representing fields of study relevant to the chronological scope of the Centre.<ref name="Administration ">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/administration/Pages/home.aspx Administration], The board of TUCEMEMS.</ref>
The board decides of the budget and of the yearly strategy of the Centre. The board is nominated by the dean of the Faculty of Humanities.<ref name="Hallinto ">[http://www.utu.fi/fi/yksikot/hum/sivustot/tucemems/hallinto/periaatteet/Sivut/home.aspx Operational principles], Operational principles of TUCEMEMS, in Finnish.</ref>
New members of TUCEMEMS are accepted by the Chairperson. An individual can be accepted as a member if he or she is researching the medieval or early modern period. The person can be a postgraduate student, a post-doc researcher or a student writing their Master’s thesis, if he or she aims to continue to doctoral studies.<ref name="Becoming a member ">[http://www.utu.fi/fi/yksikot/hum/sivustot/tucemems/jasenet/liityjaseneksi/Sivut/home.aspx Becoming a member], How to become a member of TUCEMEMS, in Finnish.</ref>
== History == TUCEMEMS was established in December 2009. The activities of the Centre expanded rapidly in 2010, at the same time as the number of members grew to around 70. The Centre also connected with other centres on the world. The activities included Monthly Talks, one symposium on Medieval and Early Modern Legal Court Records, and a three lecture series held by visiting professors and various local scholars. The Centre also funded research trips and conference journeys for some of its members.<ref name="Report2010">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/administration/annualreport/Documents/Tucemems_AnnualReport2010_publish.pdf, the annual report of TUCEMEMS for the year 2010].</ref>
In 2011 new activities were launched. The TUCEMEMS’ own research seminar started in the autumn, with six sessions held. The Centre also organised a lecture series for the general public. Theses studia generalia –lecture series have since been held every spring semester and have attracted considerable attention.<ref name="Report2011">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/administration/annualreport/Documents/tucemems_annualreport2011.pdf, the annual report of TUCEMEMS for the year 2011].</ref>
On 2012 the Centre published an anthology on the medieval and early modern Turku in Finnish. TUCEMEMS also participated in the organizing of Dies Medievales, the biannual conference of Finnish medievalists in Turku. The programme of the conference was both interdisciplinary and international, with four keynote lecturers from Finland, Sweden and France and 33 presentations in three languages.<ref name="Report2012">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/administration/annualreport/Documents/Tucemems-annualreport2012.pdf, the annual report of TUCEMEMS for the year 2012].</ref>
In 2013 The Centre started co-operation with the Amsterdam University Press for the publishing of its own scholarly series, Crossing Boundaries: Turku Medieval and Early Modern Studies. The first publication in the series will be released in 2014.{{update inline|date=August 2015}}<ref name="Report2013">[http://www.utu.fi/en/units/hum/sites/tucemems/administration/annualreport/Documents/Tucemems_AnnualReport2013.pdf, the annual report of TUCEMEMS for the year 2013].</ref>
